						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Charlie Chaplin</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="dablink">For other people named Charles Chaplin, see <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charles_Chaplin_(disambiguation)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charles Chaplin (disambiguation) (page does not exist)">Charles Chaplin (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Featured_article&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Featured article (page does not exist)">Template:Featured article</a>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-protected&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-protected (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-protected</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-move-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-move-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-move-indef</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_British_English&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use British English (page does not exist)">Template:Use British English</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_dmy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use dmy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use dmy dates</a>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Infobox_person&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Infobox person (page does not exist)">Template:Infobox person</a>
</p><p><b>Sir Charles Spencer</b> "<b>Charlie</b>" <b>Chaplin</b>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Post-nominals&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Post-nominals (page does not exist)">Template:Post-nominals</a> (16&#160;April 1889&#160;– 25&#160;December 1977) was an English comic actor, filmmaker, and composer who rose to fame in the <a href="/wiki/Silent_film" title="Silent film">silent era</a>. Chaplin became a worldwide icon through his screen persona "<a href="/wiki/The_Tramp" title="The Tramp">the Tramp</a>" and is considered one of the most important figures in the history of the film industry.<sup id="cite_ref-acclaim_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-acclaim-1">[1]</a></sup> His career spanned more than 75 years, from childhood in the <a href="/wiki/Victorian_era" title="Victorian era">Victorian era</a> until a year before his death at age 88, and encompassed both adulation and controversy.
</p><p>Chaplin's childhood in London was defined by poverty and hardship. As his father was absent and his mother struggled financially, he was sent to a <a href="/wiki/Workhouse" title="Workhouse">workhouse</a> twice before the age of nine. When he was 14, his mother was committed to a mental asylum. Chaplin began performing at an early age, touring <a href="/wiki/Music_hall" title="Music hall">music halls</a> and later working as a stage actor and comedian. At 19 he was signed to the prestigious <a href="/wiki/Fred_Karno" title="Fred Karno">Fred Karno</a> company, which took him to America. Chaplin was scouted for the film industry, and made his first appearance in <a href="/wiki/Keystone_Studios" title="Keystone Studios">Keystone Studios</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Making_a_Living" title="Making a Living">Making a Living</a></i> (1914). He soon developed the Tramp persona and formed a large fan base. Chaplin directed his films from an early stage, and continued to hone his craft as he moved to the <a href="/wiki/Essanay" title="Essanay" class="mw-redirect">Essanay</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mutual_Film&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mutual Film (page does not exist)">Mutual</a>, and <a href="/wiki/First_National" title="First National">First National</a> corporations. By 1918, he was one of the best known figures in the world.
</p><p>In 1919, Chaplin co-founded the distribution company <a href="/wiki/United_Artists" title="United Artists">United Artists</a>, which gave him complete control over his films. His first <a href="/w/index.php?title=Feature-length&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Feature-length (page does not exist)">feature-length</a> was <i><a href="/wiki/The_Kid_(1921_film)" title="The Kid (1921 film)">The Kid</a></i> (1921), followed by <i><a href="/wiki/A_Woman_of_Paris" title="A Woman of Paris">A Woman of Paris</a></i> (1923), <i><a href="/wiki/The_Gold_Rush" title="The Gold Rush">The Gold Rush</a></i> (1925), and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Circus_(film)" title="The Circus (film)">The Circus</a></i> (1928). He refused to move to <a href="/wiki/Sound_film" title="Sound film">sound films</a> in the 1930s, instead producing <i><a href="/wiki/City_Lights" title="City Lights">City Lights</a></i> (1931) and <i><a href="/wiki/Modern_Times_(film)" title="Modern Times (film)">Modern Times</a></i> (1936) without dialogue. Chaplin became increasingly political and his next film, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Great_Dictator" title="The Great Dictator">The Great Dictator</a></i> (1940), satirised <a href="/w/index.php?title=Adolf_Hitler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adolf Hitler (page does not exist)">Adolf Hitler</a>. The 1940s were a decade marked with controversy for Chaplin, and his popularity declined rapidly. He was accused of <a href="/wiki/Communist" title="Communist" class="mw-redirect">communist</a> sympathies, while his involvement in a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Paternity_suit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Paternity suit (page does not exist)">paternity suit</a> and marriages to much younger women caused  scandal. An <a href="/wiki/FBI" title="FBI" class="mw-redirect">FBI</a> investigation was opened, and Chaplin was  forced to leave the United States and settle in Switzerland. He abandoned the Tramp in his later films, which include <i><a href="/wiki/Monsieur_Verdoux" title="Monsieur Verdoux">Monsieur Verdoux</a></i> (1947), <i><a href="/wiki/Limelight_(1952_film)" title="Limelight (1952 film)">Limelight</a></i> (1952), <i><a href="/wiki/A_King_in_New_York" title="A King in New York">A King in New York</a></i> (1957), and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=A_Countess_from_Hong_Kong&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A Countess from Hong Kong (page does not exist)">A Countess from Hong Kong</a></i> (1967).
</p><p>Chaplin wrote, directed, produced, edited, starred in, and composed the music for most of his films. He was a perfectionist, and his financial independence enabled him to spend years on the development and production of a picture. His films are characterised by <a href="/wiki/Slapstick" title="Slapstick">slapstick</a> combined with <a href="/wiki/Pathos" title="Pathos">pathos</a>, typified in the Tramp's struggles against adversity. Many contain social and political themes, as well as autobiographical elements. In 1972, as part of a renewed appreciation for his work, Chaplin received an <a href="/wiki/Academy_Honorary_Award" title="Academy Honorary Award">Honorary Academy Award</a> for "the incalculable effect he has had in making motion pictures the art form of this century". He continues to be held in high regard, with <i>The Gold Rush</i>, <i>City Lights</i>, <i>Modern Times</i>, and <i>The Great Dictator</i> often ranked among industry lists of the greatest films of all time.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Biography">Biography</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_years_.281889.E2.80.931913.29">Early years (1889–1913)</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Background_and_childhood_hardship">Background and childhood hardship</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Hannah_Chaplin.jpg" title="File:Hannah Chaplin.jpg">File:Hannah Chaplin.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hannah_Chaplin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hannah Chaplin (page does not exist)">Hannah Chaplin</a>, mother</div></div></div>
<p>Charles Spencer Chaplin was born on 16&#160;April 1889 to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hannah_Chaplin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hannah Chaplin (page does not exist)">Hannah Chaplin</a> (née Hill) and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charles_Chaplin,_Sr.&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charles Chaplin, Sr. (page does not exist)">Charles Chaplin,&#160;Sr.</a> There is no official record of his birth, although Chaplin believed he was born at <a href="/w/index.php?title=East_Street&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="East Street (page does not exist)">East Street</a>, <a href="/wiki/Walworth" title="Walworth">Walworth</a>, in <a href="/wiki/South_London" title="South London">South London</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-rob10_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rob10-2">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[note 1]</a></sup> His mother and father had married four years previously, at which time Charles Sr. became the legal carer of Hannah's illegitimate son, <a href="/wiki/Sydney_Chaplin" title="Sydney Chaplin">Sydney John</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[6]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[note 2]</a></sup> At the time of his birth, Chaplin's parents were both <a href="/wiki/Music_hall" title="Music hall">music hall</a> entertainers. Hannah, the daughter of a shoemaker,<sup id="cite_ref-rob3_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rob3-8">[7]</a></sup> had a brief and unsuccessful career under the stage name Lily Harley,<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[8]</a></sup> while Charles Sr., a butcher's son,<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[9]</a></sup> was a popular singer.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[10]</a></sup> Chaplin's parents were estranged by around 1891.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[11]</a></sup> In 1892, Hannah gave birth to a third son – <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wheeler_Dryden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wheeler Dryden (page does not exist)">George Wheeler Dryden</a> – fathered by the music hall entertainer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Leo_Dryden&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Leo Dryden (page does not exist)">Leo Dryden</a>. The child was taken by Dryden at six months old, and did not re-enter Chaplin's life for 30 years.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[12]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chaplin's childhood was fraught with poverty and hardship, making his eventual trajectory "the most dramatic of all the rags to riches stories ever told" according to his authorised biographer <a href="/wiki/David_Robinson_(film_critic)" title="David Robinson (film critic)">David Robinson</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[13]</a></sup> Chaplin's early years were spent with his mother and brother Sydney in the London district of <a href="/wiki/Kennington" title="Kennington">Kennington</a>; Hannah had no means of income, other than occasional nursing and dressmaking, and Chaplin Sr. provided no support for his sons.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[14]</a></sup> As the situation deteriorated, Chaplin was sent to a <a href="/wiki/Workhouse" title="Workhouse">workhouse</a> when he was seven years old.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[note 3]</a></sup> The council housed him at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Central_London_District_School&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Central London District School (page does not exist)">Central London District School</a> for <a href="/wiki/Pauperism" title="Pauperism">paupers</a>, which Chaplin remembered as "a forlorn existence".<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[16]</a></sup> He was briefly reunited with his mother 18 months later, before Hannah was forced to readmit her family to the workhouse in July 1898. The boys were promptly sent to Norwood Schools, another institution for destitute children.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[17]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="quotebox" style="float: left; clear: left; margin: 0.5em 1.4em 0.8em 0; width: 20%; padding: 6px; border: 1px solid #aaa; font-size: 88%; background-color: #E0E6F8;">
<div style="position: relative; text-align: left;">
<div>
<p>"I was hardly aware of a crisis because we lived in a continual crisis; and, being a boy, I dismissed our troubles with gracious forgetfulness."<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[18]</a></sup>
</p>
</div>
</div>
<div style="text-align: left;">– Chaplin on his childhood</div>
</div>
<p>In September 1898, Chaplin's mother was committed to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cane_Hill&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cane Hill (page does not exist)">Cane Hill</a> mental asylum – she had developed a <a href="/wiki/Psychosis" title="Psychosis">psychosis</a> seemingly brought on by an infection of <a href="/wiki/Syphilis" title="Syphilis">syphilis</a> and malnutrition.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[19]</a></sup> For the two months she was there, Chaplin and his brother Sydney were sent to live with their father, whom the young boys scarcely knew.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[20]</a></sup> Charles Sr. was by then a severe alcoholic, and life there was bad enough to provoke a visit from the <a href="/wiki/National_Society_for_the_Prevention_of_Cruelty_to_Children" title="National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children">National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Robinson.2C_p._27_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Robinson.2C_p._27-24">[21]</a></sup> Chaplin's father died two years later, at 38 years old, from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cirrhosis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cirrhosis (page does not exist)">cirrhosis</a> of the liver.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[22]</a></sup>
</p><p>Hannah entered a period of remission,<sup id="cite_ref-Robinson.2C_p._27_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Robinson.2C_p._27-24">[21]</a></sup> but in May 1903 became ill again. Chaplin, then 14, had the task of taking his mother to the infirmary, from where she was sent back to Cane Hill.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[23]</a></sup> He lived alone for several days, searching for food and occasionally sleeping rough, until Sydney – who had enrolled in the Navy two years earlier – returned.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[24]</a></sup> Hannah was released from the asylum eight months later,<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[25]</a></sup> but in March 1905 her illness returned, this time permanently. "There was nothing we could do but accept poor mother's fate," Chaplin later wrote, and she remained in care until her death in 1928.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[26]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Young_performer">Young performer</span></h4>
<p>Between his time in the poor schools and his mother succumbing to mental illness, Chaplin began to perform on stage. He recalled making his first amateur appearance at five years old, when he took over from Hannah one night in <a href="/wiki/Aldershot" title="Aldershot">Aldershot</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[note 4]</a></sup> This was an isolated occurrence, but by the time he was nine Chaplin had, with his mother's encouragement, grown interested in performing. He later wrote: "[she] imbued me with the feeling that I had some sort of talent."<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[28]</a></sup> Through his father's connections,<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[29]</a></sup> Chaplin became a member of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Eight_Lancashire_Lads&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Eight Lancashire Lads (page does not exist)">Eight Lancashire Lads</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Clog_dancing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Clog dancing (page does not exist)">clog-dancing</a> troupe, with whom he toured English music halls throughout 1899 and 1900.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[note 5]</a></sup> Chaplin worked hard, and the act was popular with audiences, but he was not satisfied with dancing and wished to form a comedy act.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[31]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the years Chaplin was touring with the Eight Lancashire Lads, his mother ensured that he still attended school,<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[32]</a></sup> but by age 13 he had abandoned education.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[33]</a></sup> He supported himself with a range of jobs, while nursing his ambition to become an actor.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[34]</a></sup> At 14, shortly after his mother's relapse, he registered with a theatrical agency in London's <a href="/wiki/West_End_of_London" title="West End of London">West End</a>. The manager sensed potential in Chaplin, who was promptly given his first role as a newsboy in <a href="/w/index.php?title=H._A._Saintsbury&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="H. A. Saintsbury (page does not exist)">H. A. Saintsbury</a>'s <i>Jim, a Romance of Cockayne</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[35]</a></sup> It opened in July 1903, but the show was unsuccessful and closed after two weeks. Chaplin's comic performance, however, was singled out for praise in many of the reviews.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[36]</a></sup> Saintsbury secured a role for Chaplin in <a href="/wiki/Charles_Frohman" title="Charles Frohman">Charles Frohman</a>'s production of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sherlock_Holmes_(play)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sherlock Holmes (play) (page does not exist)">Sherlock Holmes</a></i>, where he played Billy the pageboy in three nationwide tours.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[37]</a></sup> His performance was so well received that he was called to London to play the role alongside <a href="/wiki/William_Gillette" title="William Gillette">William Gillette</a>, the original Holmes.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[note 6]</a></sup> "It was like tidings from heaven," Chaplin recalled.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[39]</a></sup> At 16 years old, Chaplin starred in the play's West End production at the <a href="/wiki/Duke_of_York%27s_Theatre" title="Duke of York's Theatre">Duke of York's Theatre</a> from October to December 1905.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[40]</a></sup> He completed one final tour of <i>Sherlock Holmes</i> in early 1906, before leaving the play after more than two-and-a-half years.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[41]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chaplin_Karno_advert.jpg" title="File:Chaplin Karno advert.jpg">File:Chaplin Karno advert.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Advertisement from Chaplin's American tour with the <a href="/wiki/Fred_Karno" title="Fred Karno">Fred Karno</a> comedy company, 1913</div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Stage_comedy_and_vaudeville">Stage comedy and vaudeville</span></h4>
<p>Chaplin soon found work with a new company, and went on tour with his brother – who was also pursuing an acting career – in a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Comedy_sketch&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Comedy sketch (page does not exist)">comedy sketch</a> called <i>Repairs</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[42]</a></sup> In May 1906, Chaplin joined the juvenile act <i>Casey's Circus</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[43]</a></sup> where he developed popular <a href="/wiki/Burlesque" title="Burlesque">burlesque</a> pieces and was soon the star of the show. By the time the act finished touring in July 1907, the 18-year-old had become an accomplished comedic performer.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[44]</a></sup> He struggled to find more work, however, and a brief attempt at a solo act was a failure.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[note 7]</a></sup>
</p><p>Meanwhile, Sydney Chaplin had joined <a href="/wiki/Fred_Karno" title="Fred Karno">Fred Karno</a>'s prestigious comedy company in 1906, and by 1908 he was one of their key performers.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[46]</a></sup> In February, he managed to secure a two-week trial for his younger brother. Karno was initially wary, and considered Chaplin a "pale, puny, sullen-looking youngster" who "looked much too shy to do any good in the theatre."<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[47]</a></sup> But the teenager made an impact on his first night at the <a href="/wiki/London_Coliseum" title="London Coliseum">London Coliseum</a> and he was quickly signed to a contract.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[48]</a></sup> Chaplin began by playing a series of minor parts, eventually progressing to starring roles in 1909.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[49]</a></sup> In April 1910, he was given the lead in a new sketch, <i>Jimmy the Fearless</i>. It was a big success, and Chaplin received considerable press attention.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[50]</a></sup>
</p><p>Karno selected his new star to join the section of the company that toured North America's <a href="/wiki/Vaudeville" title="Vaudeville">vaudeville</a> circuit.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[51]</a></sup> The young comedian headed the show and impressed reviewers, being described as "one of the best pantomime artists ever seen here."<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[52]</a></sup> His most successful role was a drunk called the "Inebriate Swell", which drew him significant recognition.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[53]</a></sup> The tour lasted 21 months, and the troupe returned to England in June 1912.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[54]</a></sup> Chaplin recalled that he "had a disquieting feeling of sinking back into a depressing commonplaceness", and was therefore delighted when a new tour began in October.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[55]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Entering_films_.281914.E2.80.931917.29">Entering films (1914–1917)</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Keystone">Keystone</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Multiple_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Multiple image (page does not exist)">Template:Multiple image</a>
</p><p>Six months into the second American tour, Chaplin was invited to join the New York Motion Picture Company. A representative who had seen his performances thought he could replace Fred Mace, a star of their <a href="/wiki/Keystone_Studios" title="Keystone Studios">Keystone Studios</a> who intended to leave.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[56]</a></sup> Chaplin thought the Keystone comedies "a crude mélange of rough and rumble", but liked the idea of working in films and rationalised, "Besides, it would mean a new life."<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[57]</a></sup> He met with the company, and signed a $150-per-week contract in September 1913.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chaplin arrived in Los Angeles, home of the Keystone studio, in early December 1913.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[59]</a></sup> His boss was <a href="/wiki/Mack_Sennett" title="Mack Sennett">Mack Sennett</a>, who initially expressed concern that the 24-year-old looked too young.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[60]</a></sup> He was not used in a picture until late January, during which time Chaplin attempted to learn the processes of filmmaking.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[61]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Film_reel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Film reel (page does not exist)">one-reeler</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Making_a_Living" title="Making a Living">Making a Living</a></i> marked his film acting debut, and was released on 2 February 1914. Chaplin strongly disliked the picture, but one review picked him out as "a comedian of the first water."<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[62]</a></sup> For his second appearance in front of the camera, Chaplin selected the costume with which he became identified. He described the process in his autobiography:
</p>
<blockquote class="templatequote">"I wanted everything to be a contradiction: the pants baggy, the coat tight, the hat small and the shoes large&#160;... I added a small moustache, which, I reasoned, would add age without hiding my expression. I had no idea of the character. But the moment I was dressed, the clothes and the makeup made me feel the person he was. I began to know him, and by the time I walked on stage he was fully born."<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[63]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[note 8]</a></sup>
</blockquote>
<p>The film was <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mabel%27s_Strange_Predicament&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mabel's Strange Predicament (page does not exist)">Mabel's Strange Predicament</a></i>, but "<a href="/wiki/The_Tramp" title="The Tramp">the Tramp</a>" character, as it became known, debuted to audiences in <i><a href="/wiki/Kid_Auto_Races_at_Venice" title="Kid Auto Races at Venice">Kid Auto Races at Venice</a></i> – shot later than <i>Mabel's Strange Predicament</i> but released two days earlier.<sup id="cite_ref-robi2_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-robi2-73">[65]</a></sup> Chaplin adopted the character as his screen persona, and attempted to make suggestions for the films he appeared in. These ideas were dismissed by his directors.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[66]</a></sup> During the filming of his eleventh picture, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mabel_at_the_Wheel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mabel at the Wheel (page does not exist)">Mabel at the Wheel</a></i>, he clashed with director <a href="/wiki/Mabel_Normand" title="Mabel Normand">Mabel Normand</a> and was almost released from his contract. Sennett kept him on, however, when he received orders from exhibitors for more Chaplin films. Sennett also allowed Chaplin to direct his next film himself, after Chaplin promised to pay $1,500 if the film was unsuccessful.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Caught_in_the_Rain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Caught in the Rain (page does not exist)">Caught in the Rain</a></i>, issued 4 May 1914, was Chaplin's directorial debut and was highly successful.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[68]</a></sup> Thereafter he directed almost every short film in which he appeared for Keystone,<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[69]</a></sup> at the rate of approximately one per week,<sup id="cite_ref-Kamin.2C_p._xi_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kamin.2C_p._xi-78">[70]</a></sup> a period which he later remembered as the most exciting time of his career.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[71]</a></sup> Chaplin's films introduced a slower form of comedy than the typical Keystone farce,<sup id="cite_ref-robi2_73-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-robi2-73">[65]</a></sup> and he developed a large fan base.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[72]</a></sup> In November 1914, he had a supporting role in the first <a href="/w/index.php?title=Feature_length&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Feature length (page does not exist)">feature length</a> comedy film, <i><a href="/wiki/Tillie%27s_Punctured_Romance_(1914_film)" title="Tillie's Punctured Romance (1914 film)">Tillie's Punctured Romance</a></i>, directed by Sennett and starring <a href="/wiki/Marie_Dressler" title="Marie Dressler">Marie Dressler</a>, which was a commercial success and increased his popularity.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[73]</a></sup> When Chaplin's contract came up for renewal at the end of the year, he asked for $1,000 a week – an amount Sennett refused as too large.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[74]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Essanay">Essanay</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chaplin_and_Purviance_in_Work.jpg" title="File:Chaplin and Purviance in Work.jpg">File:Chaplin and Purviance in Work.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Chaplin and <a href="/wiki/Edna_Purviance" title="Edna Purviance">Edna Purviance</a>, his regular leading lady, in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Work_(1915_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Work (1915 film) (page does not exist)">Work</a></i> (1915)</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Essanay_Studios" title="Essanay Studios">Essanay Film Manufacturing Company</a> sent Chaplin an offer of $1,250 a week with a signing bonus of $10,000. He joined the studio in late December 1914,<sup id="cite_ref-Rob135_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rob135-83">[75]</a></sup> where he began forming a stock company of regular players, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Leo_White&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Leo White (page does not exist)">Leo White</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bud_Jamison&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bud Jamison (page does not exist)">Bud Jamison</a>, Paddy McGuire and Billy Armstrong. He soon recruited a leading lady – <a href="/wiki/Edna_Purviance" title="Edna Purviance">Edna Purviance</a>, who Chaplin met in a cafe and hired on account of her beauty. She went on to appear in 35 films with Chaplin over eight years;<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[76]</a></sup> the pair also formed a romantic relationship that lasted into 1917.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[77]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chaplin asserted a high level of control over his pictures, and started to put more time and care into each film.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[78]</a></sup> There was a month-long interval between the release of his second production, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=A_Night_Out_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A Night Out (film) (page does not exist)">A Night Out</a></i>, and his third, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Champion_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Champion (film) (page does not exist)">The Champion</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[79]</a></sup> The final seven of Chaplin's 14 Essanay films were all produced at this slower pace.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[80]</a></sup> Chaplin also began to alter his screen persona, which had attracted some criticism at Keystone for its "mean, crude, and brutish" nature.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[81]</a></sup> The character became more gentle and romantic;<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[82]</a></sup> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Tramp_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Tramp (film) (page does not exist)">The Tramp</a></i> (April 1915) was considered a particular turning point in his development.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[83]</a></sup> The use of pathos was developed further with <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Bank_(1915_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Bank (1915 film) (page does not exist)">The Bank</a></i>, in which Chaplin created a sad ending. Robinson notes that this was an innovation in comedy films, and marked the time when serious critics began to appreciate Chaplin's work.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[84]</a></sup> At Essanay, writes film scholar <a href="/w/index.php?title=Simon_Louvish&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Simon Louvish (page does not exist)">Simon Louvish</a>, Chaplin "found the themes and the settings that would define the Tramp's world."<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[85]</a></sup>
</p><p>During 1915, Chaplin became a cultural phenomenon. Shops were stocked with Chaplin merchandise, he was featured in cartoons and comic strips, and several songs were written about him.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[86]</a></sup> In July, a journalist for <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Motion_Picture_Magazine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Motion Picture Magazine (page does not exist)">Motion Picture Magazine</a></i> wrote that "Chaplinitis" had spread across America.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[87]</a></sup> As his fame grew worldwide, he became the film industry's first international star.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[88]</a></sup> When the Essanay contract ended in December 1915,<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[89]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[note 9]</a></sup> Chaplin – fully aware of his popularity – requested a $150,000 signing bonus from his next studio. He received several offers, including <a href="/wiki/Universal_Studios" title="Universal Studios">Universal</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fox_Film_Corporation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fox Film Corporation (page does not exist)">Fox</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vitagraph_Studios" title="Vitagraph Studios">Vitagraph</a>, the best of which came from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mutual_Film_Corporation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mutual Film Corporation (page does not exist)">Mutual Film Corporation</a> at $10,000 a week.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[91]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Mutual">Mutual</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Charlie_Chaplin_with_doll.jpg" title="File:Charlie Chaplin with doll.jpg">File:Charlie Chaplin with doll.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">By 1916, Chaplin was a global phenomenon. Here he shows off some of his merchandise, c. 1918.</div></div></div>
<p>A contract was negotiated with Mutual that amounted to $670,000 a year, which Robinson says made Chaplin – at 26 years old – one of the highest paid people in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[92]</a></sup> The high salary shocked the public and was widely reported in the press.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[93]</a></sup> John R. Freuler, the studio President, explained, "We can afford to pay Mr. Chaplin this large sum annually because the public wants Chaplin and will pay for him."<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[94]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mutual gave Chaplin his own Los Angeles studio to work in, which opened in March 1916.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[95]</a></sup> He added two key members to his stock company, <a href="/wiki/Albert_Austin" title="Albert Austin">Albert Austin</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eric_Campbell_(actor)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eric Campbell (actor) (page does not exist)">Eric Campbell</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[96]</a></sup> and produced a series of elaborate two-reelers: <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Floorwalker&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Floorwalker (page does not exist)">The Floorwalker</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Fireman_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Fireman (film) (page does not exist)">The Fireman</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Vagabond_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Vagabond (film) (page does not exist)">The Vagabond</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=One_A.M._(1916_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="One A.M. (1916 film) (page does not exist)">One A.M.</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Count_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Count (film) (page does not exist)">The Count</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[97]</a></sup> For <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Pawnshop&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Pawnshop (page does not exist)">The Pawnshop</a></i> he recruited the actor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Henry_Bergman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Henry Bergman (page does not exist)">Henry Bergman</a>, who was to work with Chaplin for 30 years.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[98]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Behind_the_Screen" title="Behind the Screen">Behind the Screen</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Rink_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Rink (film) (page does not exist)">The Rink</a></i> completed Chaplin's releases for 1916. The Mutual contract stipulated that he release a two-reel film every four weeks, which he had managed to achieve. With the new year, however, Chaplin began to demand more time.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[99]</a></sup> He made only four more films for Mutual over the first ten months of 1917: <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Easy_Street_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Easy Street (film) (page does not exist)">Easy Street</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Cure_(1917_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Cure (1917 film) (page does not exist)">The Cure</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Immigrant_(1917_film)" title="The Immigrant (1917 film)">The Immigrant</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Adventurer_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Adventurer (film) (page does not exist)">The Adventurer</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[100]</a></sup> With their careful construction, these films are considered by Chaplin scholars to be among his finest work.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[101]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[102]</a></sup> Later in life, Chaplin referred to his Mutual years as the happiest period of his career.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[103]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chaplin was attacked in the British media for not fighting in the <a href="/wiki/First_World_War" title="First World War" class="mw-redirect">First World War</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[104]</a></sup> He defended himself, revealing that he would fight for Britain if called and had registered for the American draft, but he was not summoned by either country.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[note 10]</a></sup> Despite this criticism Chaplin was a favourite with the troops,<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[106]</a></sup> and his popularity continued to grow worldwide. <i><a href="/wiki/Harper%27s_Weekly" title="Harper's Weekly">Harper's Weekly</a></i> reported that the name of Charlie Chaplin was "a part of the common language of almost every country", and that the Tramp image was "universally familiar".<sup id="cite_ref-Rob210_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rob210-117">[107]</a></sup> In 1917, professional Chaplin imitators were so widespread that he took legal action,<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[108]</a></sup> and it was reported that nine out of ten men who attended costume parties dressed as the Tramp.<sup id="cite_ref-Rob213_119-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rob213-119">[109]</a></sup> The same year, a study by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Boston_Society_for_Psychical_Research&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Boston Society for Psychical Research (page does not exist)">Boston Society for Psychical Research</a> concluded that Chaplin was "an American obsession."<sup id="cite_ref-Rob213_119-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rob213-119">[109]</a></sup> The actress <a href="/wiki/Minnie_Maddern_Fiske" title="Minnie Maddern Fiske">Minnie Maddern Fiske</a> wrote that "a constantly increasing body of cultured, artistic people are beginning to regard the young English buffoon, Charles Chaplin, as an extraordinary artist, as well as a comic genius."<sup id="cite_ref-Rob210_117-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rob210-117">[107]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="First_National_.281918.E2.80.931922.29">First National (1918–1922)</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Poster_-_A_Dog%27s_Life_01.jpg" title="File:Poster - A Dog's Life 01.jpg">File:Poster - A Dog's Life 01.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=A_Dog%27s_Life&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A Dog's Life (page does not exist)">A Dog's Life</a></i> (1918). It was around this time that Chaplin began to conceive the Tramp as "a sort of <a href="/wiki/Pierrot" title="Pierrot">Pierrot</a>", or sad clown.</div></div></div>
<p>Mutual were patient with Chaplin's decreased rate of output, and the contract ended amicably. His primary concern in finding a new distributor was independence; Sydney Chaplin, then his business manager, told the press, "Charlie [must] be allowed all the time he needs and all the money for producing [films] the way he wants&#160;... It is quality, not quantity, we are after."<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[110]</a></sup> In June 1917, Chaplin signed to complete eight films for <a href="/wiki/First_National" title="First National">First National Exhibitors' Circuit</a> in return for $1&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-Schickel.2C_p._8_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schickel.2C_p._8-121">[111]</a></sup> He chose to build his own studio, situated on five acres of land off <a href="/wiki/Sunset_Boulevard" title="Sunset Boulevard">Sunset Boulevard</a>, with production facilities of the highest order.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[112]</a></sup> It was completed in January 1918,<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[113]</a></sup> and Chaplin was given freedom over the making of his pictures.<sup id="cite_ref-BFI_first_national_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BFI_first_national-124">[114]</a></sup>
</p><p><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=A_Dog%27s_Life&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A Dog's Life (page does not exist)">A Dog's Life</a></i>, released April 1918, was the first film under the new contract. In it, Chaplin demonstrated his increasing concern with story construction, and his treatment of the Tramp as "a sort of <a href="/wiki/Pierrot" title="Pierrot">Pierrot</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[115]</a></sup> The film was described by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Louis_Delluc&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Louis Delluc (page does not exist)">Louis Delluc</a> as "cinema's first total work of art."<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[116]</a></sup> Chaplin then embarked on the <a href="/wiki/Liberty_bond#Sales_difficulties_and_the_subsequent_campaign" title="Liberty bond">Third Liberty Bond</a> campaign, touring the United States for one month to raise money for the Allies of the First World War.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[117]</a></sup> He also produced a short <a href="/wiki/Propaganda" title="Propaganda">propaganda</a> film, donated to the government for fund-raising, called <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Bond&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Bond (page does not exist)">The Bond</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[118]</a></sup> Chaplin's next release was war-based, placing the Tramp in the trenches for <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Shoulder_Arms&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shoulder Arms (page does not exist)">Shoulder Arms</a></i>. Associates warned him against making a comedy about the war  but, as he later recalled, "Dangerous or not, the idea excited me."<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[119]</a></sup> He spent four months filming the 45-minute-long picture, which was released in October 1918 with great success.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[120]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="United_Artists.2C_Mildred_Harris.2C_and_The_Kid">United Artists, Mildred Harris, and <i>The Kid</i></span></h4>
<p>After the release of <i>Shoulder Arms</i>, Chaplin requested more money from First National, which was refused. Frustrated with their lack of concern for quality, and worried about rumours of a possible merger between the company and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Famous_Players-Lasky&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Famous Players-Lasky (page does not exist)">Famous Players-Lasky</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[121]</a></sup> Chaplin joined forces with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Douglas_Fairbanks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Douglas Fairbanks (page does not exist)">Douglas Fairbanks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mary_Pickford" title="Mary Pickford">Mary Pickford</a>, and <a href="/wiki/D._W._Griffith" title="D. W. Griffith">D. W. Griffith</a> to form a new distribution company – <a href="/wiki/United_Artists" title="United Artists">United Artists</a>, established in January 1919.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[122]</a></sup> The arrangement was revolutionary in the film industry, as it enabled the four partners – all creative artists – to personally fund their pictures and have complete control.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated4_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated4-133">[123]</a></sup> Chaplin was eager to start with the new company, and offered to buy out his contract with First National. They declined this, and insisted that he complete the final six films he owed them.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[124]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chaplin_The_Kid_2_crop.jpg" title="File:Chaplin The Kid 2 crop.jpg">File:Chaplin The Kid 2 crop.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i><a href="/wiki/The_Kid_(1921_film)" title="The Kid (1921 film)">The Kid</a></i> (1921), with <a href="/wiki/Jackie_Coogan" title="Jackie Coogan">Jackie Coogan</a>, combined comedy with drama and was Chaplin's first film to exceed an hour.</div></div></div>
<p>Before the creation of United Artists, Chaplin married for the first time. The 17-year-old actress <a href="/wiki/Mildred_Harris" title="Mildred Harris">Mildred Harris</a> had revealed that she was pregnant with his child, and in September 1918 he married her quietly in Los Angeles to avoid controversy.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[125]</a></sup> Soon after, the pregnancy was found to be a false alarm.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[126]</a></sup> Chaplin was unhappy with the union and, feeling that marriage stunted his creativity, struggled over the production of his film <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sunnyside_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sunnyside (film) (page does not exist)">Sunnyside</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[127]</a></sup> Harris was by then legitimately pregnant, and on 7 July 1919, gave birth to a son. Norman Spencer Chaplin was born malformed, and died three days later.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[128]</a></sup> The marriage eventually ended in April 1920, with Chaplin explaining in his autobiography that they were "irreconcilably mismated".<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[129]</a></sup>
</p><p>Losing a child is thought to have influenced Chaplin's work, as he planned a film which turned the Tramp into the caretaker of a young boy.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[130]</a></sup> For this new venture, Chaplin also wished to do more than comedy and, according to Louvish, "make his mark on a changed world."<sup id="cite_ref-Louvish_146_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Louvish_146-141">[131]</a></sup> Filming on <i><a href="/wiki/The_Kid_(1921_film)" title="The Kid (1921 film)">The Kid</a></i> began in August 1919, with four-year-old <a href="/wiki/Jackie_Coogan" title="Jackie Coogan">Jackie Coogan</a> his co-star.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[132]</a></sup> It occurred to Chaplin that it was turning into a large project, so to placate First National, he halted production and quickly filmed <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=A_Day%27s_Pleasure&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A Day's Pleasure (page does not exist)">A Day's Pleasure</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[133]</a></sup> <i>The Kid</i> was in production for nine months, until May 1920, and at 68 minutes it was Chaplin's longest picture to date.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[134]</a></sup> Dealing with issues of poverty and parent–child separation, <i>The Kid</i> is thought to have been influenced by Chaplin's own childhood<sup id="cite_ref-BFI_first_national_124-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BFI_first_national-124">[114]</a></sup> and was one of the earliest films to combine comedy and drama.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[135]</a></sup> It was released in January 1921 with instant success, and by 1924 had been screened in over 50 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[136]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chaplin spent five months on his next film, the two-reeler <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Idle_Class&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Idle Class (page does not exist)">The Idle Class</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated4_133-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated4-133">[123]</a></sup> Following its September 1921 release, he chose to return to England for the first time in almost a decade.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[137]</a></sup> He then worked to fulfil his First National contract, releasing <i><a href="/wiki/Pay_Day_(1922_film)" title="Pay Day (1922 film)">Pay Day</a></i> in February 1922. <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Pilgrim_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Pilgrim (film) (page does not exist)">The Pilgrim</a></i> – his final short film – was delayed by distribution disagreements with the studio, and released a year later.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[138]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Silent_features_.281923.E2.80.931938.29">Silent features (1923–1938)</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="A_Woman_of_Paris_and_The_Gold_Rush"><i>A Woman of Paris</i> and <i>The Gold Rush</i></span></h4>
<p>Having fulfilled his First National contract, Chaplin was free to make his first picture as an independent producer. In November 1922 he began filming <i><a href="/wiki/A_Woman_of_Paris" title="A Woman of Paris">A Woman of Paris</a></i>, a romantic drama about ill-fated lovers.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[139]</a></sup> Chaplin intended it to be a star-making vehicle for Edna Purviance,<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[140]</a></sup> and did not appear in the picture himself other than in a brief, uncredited cameo.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[141]</a></sup> He wished for the film to have a realistic feel, and directed his cast to give restrained performances. In real life, he explained, "men and women try to hide their emotions rather than seek to express them".<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[142]</a></sup> <i>A Woman of Paris</i> premiered in September 1923 and was acclaimed for its subtle approach, then an innovation.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[143]</a></sup> The public, however, seemed to have little interest in a Chaplin film without his presence, and it was a box-office disappointment.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[144]</a></sup> The filmmaker was hurt by this failure – he had long wanted to produce a dramatic film and was proud of the result – and withdrew <i>A Woman of Paris</i> from circulation as soon as he could.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[145]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chaplin_the_gold_rush_boot.jpg" title="File:Chaplin the gold rush boot.jpg">File:Chaplin the gold rush boot.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Tramp resorts to eating his boot in a famous scene from <i><a href="/wiki/The_Gold_Rush" title="The Gold Rush">The Gold Rush</a></i> (1925)</div></div></div>
<p>Chaplin returned to comedy for his next project. Setting his standards high, he told himself, "This next film must be an epic! The Greatest!"<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[146]</a></sup> Inspired by a photograph of the 1898 <a href="/wiki/Klondike_Gold_Rush" title="Klondike Gold Rush">Klondike Gold Rush</a>, and later the story of the <a href="/wiki/Donner_Party" title="Donner Party">Donner Party</a> of 1846–47, he made what Geoffrey Macnab calls "an epic comedy out of grim subject matter."<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[147]</a></sup> In <i><a href="/wiki/The_Gold_Rush" title="The Gold Rush">The Gold Rush</a></i>, the Tramp is a lonely <a href="/wiki/Prospecting" title="Prospecting">prospector</a> fighting adversity and looking for love. With <a href="/w/index.php?title=Georgia_Hale&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Georgia Hale (page does not exist)">Georgia Hale</a> as his new leading lady, Chaplin began filming the picture in February 1924.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[148]</a></sup> Its elaborate production, costing almost $1 million,<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[149]</a></sup> included <a href="/wiki/Location_shooting" title="Location shooting">location shooting</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Truckee_Range" title="Truckee Range">Truckee mountains</a> with 600 extras, extravagant sets, and <a href="/wiki/Special_effect" title="Special effect">special effects</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[150]</a></sup> The last scene was not shot until May 1925, after 15 months of filming.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[151]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chaplin felt <i>The Gold Rush</i> was the best film he had made to that point.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[152]</a></sup> It opened in August 1925 and became one of the highest-grossing films of the silent era with a profit of $5 million.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[153]</a></sup> The comedy contains some of Chaplin's most famous sequences, such as the Tramp eating his shoe and the "Dance of the Rolls".<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[154]</a></sup> Macnab has called it "the quintessential Chaplin film", and Chaplin later said it was the picture he would most like to be remembered for.<sup id="cite_ref-kemp64_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kemp64-165">[155]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Lita_Grey_and_The_Circus">Lita Grey and <i>The Circus</i></span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lita_Grey_1929.jpg" title="File:Lita Grey 1929.jpg">File:Lita Grey 1929.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lita_Grey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lita Grey (page does not exist)">Lita Grey</a>, Chaplin's second wife, two years after their bitter divorce</div></div></div>
<p>While making <i>The Gold Rush</i>, Chaplin married for the second time. Mirroring the circumstances of his first union, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lita_Grey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lita Grey (page does not exist)">Lita Grey</a> was a teenage actress, originally set to star in the film, whose surprise announcement of pregnancy forced Chaplin into marriage. She was 16 and he was 35, meaning Chaplin could have been charged with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Statutory_rape&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Statutory rape (page does not exist)">statutory rape</a> under California law.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[156]</a></sup> He therefore arranged a discreet marriage in Mexico on 24 November 1924.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[157]</a></sup> Their first son, <a href="/wiki/Charles_Chaplin,_Jr." title="Charles Chaplin, Jr.">Charles Spencer Chaplin, Jr.</a>, was born on 5 May 1925, followed by <a href="/wiki/Sydney_Chaplin_(actor)" title="Sydney Chaplin (actor)">Sydney Earle Chaplin</a> on 30 March 1926.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[158]</a></sup>
</p><p>It was an unhappy marriage, and Chaplin spent long hours at the studio to avoid seeing his wife.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[159]</a></sup> In November 1926, Grey took the children and left the family home.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[160]</a></sup> A bitter divorce followed, in which Grey's application – accusing Chaplin of infidelity, abuse, and of harbouring "perverted sexual desires" – was leaked to the press.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[161]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[note 11]</a></sup> Chaplin was reported to be in the state of a nervous breakdown, as the story became headline news and groups formed across America calling for his films to be banned.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[163]</a></sup> Eager to end the case without further scandal, Chaplin's lawyers agreed to a cash settlement of $600,000 – the largest awarded by American courts at that time.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[164]</a></sup> His fanbase was strong enough to survive the incident, and it was soon forgotten, but Chaplin was deeply affected by it.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[165]</a></sup>
</p><p>Before the divorce suit was filed, Chaplin had begun work on a new film, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Circus_(film)" title="The Circus (film)">The Circus</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Rob360_177-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rob360-177">[166]</a></sup> He built a story around the idea of walking a tightrope while besieged by monkeys, and turned the Tramp into the accidental star of a circus.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[167]</a></sup> Filming was suspended for 10 months while he dealt with the divorce scandal,<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[168]</a></sup> and it was generally a trouble-ridden production.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[169]</a></sup> Finally completed in October 1927, <i>The Circus</i> was released in January 1928 to a positive reception.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_181-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-181">[170]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/1st_Academy_Awards" title="1st Academy Awards">1st Academy Awards</a>, Chaplin was given a special trophy "For versatility and genius in acting, writing, directing and producing <i>The Circus</i>."<sup id="cite_ref-circus_182-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-circus-182">[171]</a></sup> Despite its success, he permanently associated the film with the stress of its production; Chaplin omitted <i>The Circus</i> from his autobiography, and struggled to work on it when he recorded the score in his later years.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[172]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="City_Lights"><i>City Lights</i></span></h4>
<div class="quotebox" style="float: right; clear: right; margin: 0.5em 0 0.8em 1.4em; width: 25%; padding: 6px; border: 1px solid #aaa; font-size: 88%; background-color: #E0E6F8;">
<div style="position: relative; text-align: left;">
<div>
<p>"I was determined to continue making silent films&#160;... I was a pantomimist and in that medium I was unique and, without false modesty, a master."<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[173]</a></sup>
</p>
</div>
</div>
<div style="text-align: left;">—Chaplin explaining his defiance against <a href="/wiki/Sound_film" title="Sound film">sound</a> in the 1930s</div>
</div>
<p>By the time <i>The Circus</i> was released, Hollywood had witnessed the introduction of <a href="/wiki/Sound_film" title="Sound film">sound films</a>. Chaplin was cynical about this new medium and the technical shortcomings it presented, believing that "talkies" lacked the artistry of silent films.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[174]</a></sup> He was also hesitant to change the formula that had brought him such success,<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[175]</a></sup> and feared that giving the Tramp a voice would limit his international appeal.<sup id="cite_ref-Rob389_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rob389-187">[176]</a></sup> He therefore rejected the new Hollywood craze and began work on a new silent film. Chaplin was nonetheless anxious about this decision, and remained so throughout the film's production.<sup id="cite_ref-Rob389_187-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rob389-187">[176]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chaplin_City_Lights_still.jpg" title="File:Chaplin City Lights still.jpg">File:Chaplin City Lights still.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i><a href="/wiki/City_Lights" title="City Lights">City Lights</a></i> (1931), regarded as one of Chaplin's finest works</div></div></div>
<p>When filming began at the end of 1928, Chaplin had been working on the story for almost a year.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[177]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/City_Lights" title="City Lights">City Lights</a></i> followed the Tramp's love for a blind flower girl (played by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Virginia_Cherrill&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Virginia Cherrill (page does not exist)">Virginia Cherrill</a>) and his efforts to raise money for her sight-saving operation. It was a challenging production that lasted 21 months,<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[178]</a></sup> with Chaplin later confessing that he "had worked himself into a neurotic state of wanting perfection".<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-190">[179]</a></sup> One advantage Chaplin found in sound technology was the opportunity to record a musical score for the film, which he partly composed himself.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_190-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-190">[179]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[180]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chaplin finished editing <i>City Lights</i> in December 1930, by which time silent films were an anachronism.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[181]</a></sup> A preview before an unsuspecting public audience was not a success,<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[182]</a></sup> but a showing for the press produced positive reviews. One journalist wrote, "Nobody in the world but Charlie Chaplin could have done it. He is the only person that has that peculiar something called 'audience appeal' in sufficient quality to defy the popular penchant for movies that talk."<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[183]</a></sup> Given its general release in January 1931, <i>City Lights</i> proved to be a popular and financial success – eventually grossing over $3 million.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[184]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/British_Film_Institute" title="British Film Institute">British Film Institute</a> cites it as Chaplin's finest accomplishment, and the critic <a href="/wiki/James_Agee" title="James Agee">James Agee</a> hails the closing scene as "the greatest piece of acting and the highest moment in movies".<sup id="cite_ref-bfi_great_features_196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bfi_great_features-196">[185]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[186]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Travels.2C_Paulette_Goddard.2C_and_Modern_Times">Travels, Paulette Goddard, and <i>Modern Times</i></span></h4>
<p><i>City Lights</i> had been a success, but Chaplin was unsure if he could make another picture without dialogue. He remained convinced that sound would not work in his films, but was also "obsessed by a depressing fear of being old-fashioned."<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[187]</a></sup> In this state of uncertainty, early in 1931 the comedian decided to take a holiday and ended up travelling for 16 months.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[188]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[note 12]</a></sup> In his autobiography, Chaplin recalled that on his return to Los Angeles, "I was confused and without plan, restless and conscious of an extreme loneliness". He briefly considered the option of retiring and moving to China.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[191]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Modern_Times_poster.jpg" title="File:Modern Times poster.jpg">File:Modern Times poster.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i><a href="/wiki/Modern_Times_(film)" title="Modern Times (film)">Modern Times</a></i> (1936), described by Jérôme Larcher as a "grim contemplation on the automatization of the individual"<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[192]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Chaplin's loneliness was relieved when he met 21-year-old actress <a href="/wiki/Paulette_Goddard" title="Paulette Goddard">Paulette Goddard</a> in July 1932, and the pair began a successful relationship.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[193]</a></sup> He was not ready to commit to a film, however, and focussed on writing a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Serial_(literature)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Serial (literature) (page does not exist)">serial</a> about his travels (published in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Woman%27s_Home_Companion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Woman's Home Companion (page does not exist)">Woman's Home Companion</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[194]</a></sup> The trip had been a stimulating experience for Chaplin, including meetings with several prominent thinkers, and he became increasingly interested in world affairs.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[195]</a></sup> The state of labour in America troubled him, and he feared that capitalism and machinery in the workplace would increase unemployment levels. It was these concerns that stimulated Chaplin to develop his new film.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[196]</a></sup>
</p><p><i><a href="/wiki/Modern_Times_(film)" title="Modern Times (film)">Modern Times</a></i> was announced by Chaplin as "a satire on certain phases of our industrial life."<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[197]</a></sup> Featuring the Tramp and Goddard as they endure the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Depression&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Depression (page does not exist)">Great Depression</a>, it took ten and a half months to film.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[198]</a></sup> Chaplin intended to use spoken dialogue, but  changed his mind during rehearsals. Like its predecessor, <i>Modern Times</i> employed sound effects, but almost no speaking.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[199]</a></sup> Chaplin's performance of a gibberish song did, however, give the Tramp a voice for the only time on film.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[200]</a></sup> After recording the music, Chaplin released <i>Modern Times</i> in February 1936.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[201]</a></sup> It was his first feature in 15 years to adopt political references and social realism,<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[202]</a></sup> a factor that attracted  considerable press coverage despite Chaplin's attempts  to downplay the issue.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[203]</a></sup> The film earned less at the box-office than his previous features and received mixed reviews, as some viewers disliked the politicising.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[204]</a></sup> Today, <i>Modern Times</i> is seen by the British Film Institute as one of Chaplin's "great features,"<sup id="cite_ref-bfi_great_features_196-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bfi_great_features-196">[185]</a></sup> while David Robinson says it shows the filmmaker at "his unrivalled peak as a creator of visual comedy."<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[205]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the release of <i>Modern Times</i>, Chaplin left with Goddard for a trip to the Far East.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[206]</a></sup> The couple had refused to comment on the nature of their relationship, and it was not known whether they were married or not.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[207]</a></sup> Some time later, Chaplin revealed that they married in <a href="/wiki/Guangzhou" title="Guangzhou">Canton</a> during this trip.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[208]</a></sup> By 1938 the couple had drifted apart, as both focussed heavily on their work; Goddard eventually divorced Chaplin in Mexico in 1942, citing incompatibility and separation for more than a year.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[209]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Controversies_and_fading_popularity_.281939.E2.80.931952.29">Controversies and fading popularity (1939–1952)</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Great_Dictator"><i>The Great Dictator</i></span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Great_Dictator_still_cropped.jpg" title="File:The Great Dictator still cropped.jpg">File:The Great Dictator still cropped.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Chaplin satirising <a href="/w/index.php?title=Adolf_Hitler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adolf Hitler (page does not exist)">Adolf Hitler</a> in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Great_Dictator" title="The Great Dictator">The Great Dictator</a></i> (1940)</div></div></div>
<p>The 1940s saw Chaplin face a series of controversies, both in his work and in his personal life, which changed his fortunes and severely affected his popularity in America. The first of these was a new boldness in expressing his political beliefs. Deeply disturbed by the <a href="/wiki/Fascism#International_impact_of_the_Great_Depression_and_the_buildup_to_World_War_II" title="Fascism">surge of militaristic nationalism</a> in 1930s world politics,<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[210]</a></sup> Chaplin found that he could not keep these issues out of his work.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[211]</a></sup> Parallels between himself and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Adolf_Hitler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adolf Hitler (page does not exist)">Adolf Hitler</a> had been widely noted: the pair were born four days apart, both had risen from poverty to world prominence, and the German dictator wore the same <a href="/wiki/Toothbrush_moustache" title="Toothbrush moustache">toothbrush moustache</a> as the Tramp. It was this perceived physical resemblance that supplied the pretext for the plot for Chaplin's next film, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Great_Dictator" title="The Great Dictator">The Great Dictator</a></i>, which directly satirised Hitler and attacked fascism.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[212]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chaplin spent two years developing the script,<sup id="cite_ref-Chap388_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chap388-225">[213]</a></sup> and began filming in September 1939 – six days after Britain declared war on Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[214]</a></sup> He had submitted to using spoken dialogue, partly out of acceptance that he had no other choice, but also because he recognised it as a better method for delivering a political message.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[215]</a></sup> Making a comedy about Hitler was seen as highly controversial, but Chaplin's financial independence allowed him to take the risk.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[216]</a></sup> "I was determined to go ahead," he later wrote, "for Hitler must be laughed at."<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[217]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[note 13]</a></sup> Chaplin replaced the Tramp (while wearing similar attire) with "A Jewish Barber", a reference to the Nazi party's belief that he was a Jew.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[note 14]</a></sup> In a dual performance he also played the dictator "Adenoid Hynkel", who parodied Hitler.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[219]</a></sup>
</p><p><i>The Great Dictator</i> spent a year in production, and was released in October 1940.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[220]</a></sup> There was a vast amount of publicity around the film, with a critic for the <i>New York Times</i> calling it "the most eagerly awaited picture of the year", and it was one of the biggest money-makers of the era.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[221]</a></sup> The ending was unpopular, however, and generated controversy.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[222]</a></sup> Chaplin concluded the film with a six-minute speech in which he looked into the camera and professed his personal beliefs.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[223]</a></sup> Charles J. Maland has identified this overt preaching as triggering a decline in Chaplin's popularity, and writes, "Henceforth, no movie fan would ever be able to separate the dimension of politics from [his] star image".<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[224]</a></sup> <i>The Great Dictator</i> received five Academy Award nominations, including <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Best Picture</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_Award_for_Best_Writing_(Original_Screenplay)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy Award for Best Writing (Original Screenplay) (page does not exist)">Best Original Screenplay</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_Award_for_Best_Actor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy Award for Best Actor (page does not exist)">Best Actor</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[225]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Legal_troubles_and_Oona_O.27Neill">Legal troubles and Oona O'Neill</span></h4>
