<p>In the mid-1940s, Chaplin was involved in a series of trials that occupied most of his time and significantly affected his public image.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[226]</a></sup> The troubles stemmed from his affair with an aspirant actress named <a href="/w/index.php?title=Joan_Barry_(American_actress)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Joan Barry (American actress) (page does not exist)">Joan Barry</a>, with whom he was involved intermittently between June 1941 and the autumn of 1942.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[227]</a></sup> Barry, who displayed obsessive behaviour and was twice arrested after they separated,<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[note 15]</a></sup> reappeared the following year and announced that she was pregnant with Chaplin's child. As Chaplin denied the claim, Barry filed a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Paternity_suit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Paternity suit (page does not exist)">paternity suit</a> against him.<sup id="cite_ref-Barry_242-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barry-242">[228]</a></sup>
</p><p>The director of the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation" title="Federal Bureau of Investigation">Federal Bureau of Investigation</a> (FBI), <a href="/wiki/J._Edgar_Hoover" title="J. Edgar Hoover">J. Edgar Hoover</a>, who had long been suspicious of Chaplin's political leanings, used the opportunity to generate negative publicity around him. As part of a <a href="/wiki/Smear_campaign" title="Smear campaign">smear campaign</a> to damage Chaplin's image,<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[229]</a></sup> the FBI named him in four <a href="/wiki/Indictments" title="Indictments" class="mw-redirect">indictments</a> related to the Barry case. Most serious of these was an alleged violation of the <a href="/wiki/Mann_Act" title="Mann Act">Mann Act</a>, which prohibits the transportation of women across state boundaries for sexual purposes.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[note 16]</a></sup> The historian Otto Friedrich has called this an "absurd prosecution" of an "ancient statute",<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[232]</a></sup> yet if Chaplin was found guilty, he faced 23 years in jail.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[233]</a></sup> Three charges lacked sufficient evidence to proceed to court, but the Mann Act trial began in March 1944. Chaplin was <a href="/wiki/Acquittal" title="Acquittal">acquitted</a> two weeks later.<sup id="cite_ref-Barry3_245-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barry3-245">[230]</a></sup> The case was frequently headline news, with <i><a href="/wiki/Newsweek" title="Newsweek">Newsweek</a></i> calling it the "biggest public relations scandal since the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fatty_Arbuckle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fatty Arbuckle (page does not exist)">Fatty Arbuckle</a> murder trial in 1921."<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[234]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Oona_Oneil_-_1943.jpg" title="File:Oona Oneil - 1943.jpg">File:Oona Oneil - 1943.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Chaplin's fourth wife <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oona_O%27Neill&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oona O'Neill (page does not exist)">Oona O'Neill</a>, to whom he was married from 1943 until his death. The couple had eight children.</div></div></div>
<p>Barry's child, Carole Ann, was born in October 1944, and the paternity suit went to court in February 1945. After two arduous trials, in which the prosecuting lawyer accused him of "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Moral_turpitude&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Moral turpitude (page does not exist)">moral turpitude</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[235]</a></sup> Chaplin was declared to be the father. The judge refused to accept the medical evidence of blood tests which indicated otherwise, and ordered Chaplin to pay child support until Carole Ann turned 21.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[note 17]</a></sup> Media coverage of the paternity suit was influenced by the FBI, as information was fed to the prominent gossip columnist <a href="/wiki/Hedda_Hopper" title="Hedda Hopper">Hedda Hopper</a>, and Chaplin was portrayed in an overwhelmingly critical light.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[237]</a></sup>
</p><p>The controversy surrounding Chaplin increased when, two weeks after the paternity suit was filed, it was announced that he had married his newest <a href="/w/index.php?title=Prot%C3%A9g%C3%A9e&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Protégée (page does not exist)">protégée</a>, 18-year-old <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oona_O%27Neill&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oona O'Neill (page does not exist)">Oona O'Neill</a> – daughter of the American playwright <a href="/wiki/Eugene_O%27Neill" title="Eugene O'Neill">Eugene O'Neill</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[238]</a></sup> Chaplin, then 54, had been introduced to her by a film agent seven months earlier.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[note 18]</a></sup> In his autobiography, Chaplin described meeting O'Neill as "the happiest event of my life", and claimed to have found "perfect love".<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[241]</a></sup> Chaplin's son, Charles Jr., reported that Oona "worshipped" his father.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[242]</a></sup> The couple remained married until Chaplin's death, and had eight children over 18 years: <a href="/wiki/Geraldine_Chaplin" title="Geraldine Chaplin">Geraldine Leigh</a> (b. July 1944), <a href="/wiki/Michael_Chaplin_(actor)" title="Michael Chaplin (actor)">Michael John</a> (b. March 1946), <a href="/wiki/Josephine_Chaplin" title="Josephine Chaplin">Josephine Hannah</a> (b. March 1949), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Victoria_Chaplin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Victoria Chaplin (page does not exist)">Victoria</a> (b. May 1951), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eugene_Chaplin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eugene Chaplin (page does not exist)">Eugene Anthony</a> (b. August 1953), Jane Cecil (b. May 1957), Annette Emily (b. December 1959), and <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Chaplin" title="Christopher Chaplin">Christopher James</a> (b. July 1962).<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[243]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Monsieur_Verdoux_and_communist_accusations"><i>Monsieur Verdoux</i> and communist accusations</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Monsieur_Verdoux_poster.jpg" title="File:Monsieur Verdoux poster.jpg">File:Monsieur Verdoux poster.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i><a href="/wiki/Monsieur_Verdoux" title="Monsieur Verdoux">Monsieur Verdoux</a></i> (1947), a dark comedy about a serial killer, marked a significant departure for Chaplin. He was so unpopular at the time of release that it flopped in the United States.</div></div></div>
<p>Chaplin claimed that the Barry trials had "crippled [his] creativeness", and it was some time before he began working again.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">[244]</a></sup> In April 1946, he finally began filming a project that had been in development since 1942.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[245]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Monsieur_Verdoux" title="Monsieur Verdoux">Monsieur Verdoux</a></i> was a <a href="/wiki/Black_comedy" title="Black comedy">black comedy</a>, the story of a French bank clerk, Verdoux (Chaplin), who loses his job and begins marrying and murdering wealthy widows to support his family. Chaplin's inspiration for the project came from <a href="/wiki/Orson_Welles" title="Orson Welles">Orson Welles</a>, who wanted him to star in a film about the French <a href="/wiki/Serial_killer" title="Serial killer">serial killer</a> <a href="/wiki/Henri_D%C3%A9sir%C3%A9_Landru" title="Henri Désiré Landru">Henri Désiré Landru</a>. Chaplin decided that the concept would "make a wonderful comedy",<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[246]</a></sup> and paid Welles $5,000 for the idea.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[247]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chaplin again vocalised his political views in <i>Monsieur Verdoux</i>, criticising <a href="/wiki/Capitalism" title="Capitalism">capitalism</a> and arguing that the world encourages mass killing through wars and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Weapons_of_mass_destruction&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Weapons of mass destruction (page does not exist)">weapons of mass destruction</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[248]</a></sup> Because of this, the film met with controversy when it was released in April 1947;<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[249]</a></sup> Chaplin was booed at the premiere, and there were calls for a boycott.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[250]</a></sup> <i>Monsieur Verdoux</i> was the first Chaplin release that failed both critically and commercially in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[251]</a></sup> It was more successful abroad,<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[252]</a></sup> and Chaplin's screenplay was nominated at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=20th_Academy_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="20th Academy Awards (page does not exist)">Academy Awards</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[253]</a></sup> He was proud of the film, writing in his autobiography, "<i>Monsieur Verdoux</i> is the cleverest and most brilliant film I have yet made."<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[254]</a></sup>
</p><p>The negative reaction to <i>Monsieur Verdoux</i> was largely the result of changes in Chaplin's public image.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[255]</a></sup> Along with damage of the Joan Barry scandal, he was publicly accused of being a <a href="/wiki/Communist" title="Communist" class="mw-redirect">communist</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[256]</a></sup> His political activity had heightened during World War II, when he campaigned for the opening of a Second Front to help the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and supported various Soviet–American friendship groups.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[257]</a></sup> He socialised with known communists, such as <a href="/wiki/Hanns_Eisler" title="Hanns Eisler">Hanns Eisler</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bertolt_Brecht&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bertolt Brecht (page does not exist)">Bertolt Brecht</a>, and he attended functions given by Soviet diplomats in Los Angeles.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[258]</a></sup> In the political climate of 1940s America, such activities meant Chaplin was considered, as Larcher writes, "dangerously <a href="/w/index.php?title=Progressivism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Progressivism (page does not exist)">progressive</a> and amoral."<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[259]</a></sup> The FBI wanted him out of the country,<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[260]</a></sup> and early in 1947 they launched an official investigation.<sup id="cite_ref-MalandFBI_279-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MalandFBI-279">[261]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[note 19]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chaplin denied being a communist, instead calling himself a "peacemonger",<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[263]</a></sup> but felt the government's effort to suppress the ideology was an unacceptable infringement of <a href="/wiki/Civil_liberties" title="Civil liberties">civil liberties</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[264]</a></sup> Unwilling to be quiet about the issue, he openly protested the trials of <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_USA" title="Communist Party USA">Communist Party</a> members and the activities of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=House_Un-American_Activities_Committee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="House Un-American Activities Committee (page does not exist)">House Un-American Activities Committee</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[265]</a></sup> Chaplin received a <a href="/wiki/Subpoena" title="Subpoena">subpoena</a> to appear before HUAC, but was not called to testify.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">[266]</a></sup> As his activities were widely reported in the press, and <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> fears grew, questions were raised over his failure to take American citizenship.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[267]</a></sup> Calls were made for him to be deported; Representative <a href="/wiki/John_E._Rankin" title="John E. Rankin">John E. Rankin</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mississippi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mississippi (page does not exist)">Mississippi</a> told <a href="/wiki/United_States_Congress" title="United States Congress">Congress</a> in June 1947: "His very life in Hollywood is detrimental to the moral fabric of America. [If he is deported]&#160;... his loathsome pictures can be kept from before the eyes of the American youth. He should be deported and gotten rid of at once."<sup id="cite_ref-rob545_287-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rob545-287">[268]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Limelight_and_banning_from_the_United_States"><i>Limelight</i> and banning from the United States</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Limelight_promo_crop.jpg" title="File:Limelight promo crop.jpg">File:Limelight promo crop.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i><a href="/wiki/Limelight_(1952_film)" title="Limelight (1952 film)">Limelight</a></i> (1952) was a serious and autobiographical film for Chaplin: his character, Calvero, is an ex-<a href="/wiki/Music_hall" title="Music hall">music hall</a> star (described in this image as a "Tramp Comedian") forced to deal with his loss of popularity.</div></div></div>
<p>Although Chaplin remained politically active in the years following the failure of <i>Monsieur Verdoux</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[note 20]</a></sup> his next film, about a forgotten vaudeville comedian and a young ballerina in <a href="/wiki/Edwardian_era" title="Edwardian era">Edwardian</a> London, was devoid of political themes. <i><a href="/wiki/Limelight_(1952_film)" title="Limelight (1952 film)">Limelight</a></i> was heavily autobiographical, alluding not only to Chaplin's childhood and the lives of his parents, but also to his loss of popularity in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[270]</a></sup> The cast included various members of his family, including his five oldest children and his half-brother, Wheeler Dryden.<sup id="cite_ref-Limelight1_291-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Limelight1-291">[271]</a></sup>
</p><p>Filming began in November 1951, by which time Chaplin had spent three years working on the story.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[272]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[note 21]</a></sup> He aimed for a more serious tone than any of his previous films, regularly using the word "melancholy" when explaining his plans to his co-star <a href="/wiki/Claire_Bloom" title="Claire Bloom">Claire Bloom</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[274]</a></sup> <i>Limelight</i> is also notable for a cameo appearance from <a href="/wiki/Buster_Keaton" title="Buster Keaton">Buster Keaton</a>, whom Chaplin cast as his stage partner in a pantomime scene. This marked the only time the comedians worked together.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[275]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chaplin decided to hold the world premiere of <i>Limelight</i> in London, since it was the setting of the film.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[276]</a></sup> As he left Los Angeles, he expressed a premonition that he would not be returning.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[277]</a></sup> At New York, he boarded the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:RMS&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:RMS (page does not exist)">Template:RMS</a> with his family on 18 September 1952.<sup id="cite_ref-Limelight2_299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Limelight2-299">[278]</a></sup> The next day, <a href="/wiki/United_States_Attorney_General" title="United States Attorney General">Attorney General</a> <a href="/wiki/James_P._McGranery" title="James P. McGranery">James P. McGranery</a> revoked Chaplin's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Re-entry_permit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Re-entry permit (page does not exist)">re-entry permit</a> and stated that he would have to submit to an interview concerning his political views and moral behaviour in order to re-enter the US.<sup id="cite_ref-Limelight2_299-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Limelight2-299">[278]</a></sup> Although McGranery told the press that he had "a pretty good case against Chaplin", Maland has concluded, on the basis of the FBI files that were released in the 1980s, that the US government had no real evidence to prevent Chaplin's re-entry. It is likely that he would have gained entry if he had applied for it.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[279]</a></sup> However, when Chaplin received a cablegram informing him of the news, he privately decided to cut his ties with the United States:
</p>
<blockquote class="templatequote">"Whether I re-entered that unhappy country or not was of little consequence to me. I would like to have told them that the sooner I was rid of that hate-beleaguered atmosphere the better, that I was fed up of America's insults and moral pomposity"<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[280]</a></sup>
</blockquote>
<p>Because all of his property remained in America, Chaplin refrained from saying anything negative about the incident to the press.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[281]</a></sup> The scandal attracted vast attention,<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[282]</a></sup> but Chaplin and his film were warmly received in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-Limelight2_299-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Limelight2-299">[278]</a></sup> In America the hostility towards him continued, and, although it received some positive reviews, <i>Limelight</i> was subjected to a wide-scale boycott.<sup id="cite_ref-Limelight3_304-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Limelight3-304">[283]</a></sup> Reflecting on this, Maland writes that Chaplin's fall, from an "unprecedented" level of popularity, "may be the most dramatic in the history of stardom in America".<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">[284]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="European_years_.281953.E2.80.931977.29">European years (1953–1977)</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Move_to_Switzerland_and_A_King_in_New_York">Move to Switzerland and <i>A King in New York</i></span></h4>
<div class="quotebox" style="float: left; clear: left; margin: 0.5em 1.4em 0.8em 0; width: 20%; padding: 6px; border: 1px solid #aaa; font-size: 88%; background-color: #E0E6F8;">
<div style="position: relative; text-align: left;">
<div>
<p>"I have been the object of lies and propaganda by powerful reactionary groups who, by their influence and by the aid of America's yellow press, have created an unhealthy atmosphere in which liberal-minded individuals can be singled out and persecuted. Under these conditions I find it virtually impossible to continue my motion-picture work, and I have therefore given up my residence in the United States."<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[285]</a></sup>
</p>
</div>
</div>
<div style="text-align: left;">—Chaplin's press release regarding his decision not to seek re-entry to the US</div>
</div>
<p>Chaplin did not attempt to return to the United States after his re-entry permit was revoked, and instead sent his wife to settle his affairs.<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">[note 22]</a></sup> The couple decided to settle in Switzerland, and in January 1953 the family moved into their permanent home: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Manoir_de_Ban&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Manoir de Ban (page does not exist)">Manoir de Ban</a>, a 37-acre estate overlooking <a href="/wiki/Lake_Geneva" title="Lake Geneva">Lake Geneva</a> in <a href="/wiki/Corsier-sur-Vevey" title="Corsier-sur-Vevey">Corsier-sur-Vevey</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Rob580_309-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rob580-309">[287]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[note 23]</a></sup> Chaplin put his Beverly Hills house and studio up for sale in March, and surrendered his re-entry permit in April. The next year, his wife renounced her US citizenship and became a British citizen.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[289]</a></sup> Chaplin severed the last of his professional ties with the United States in 1955, when he sold the remainder of his stock in United Artists, which had been in financial difficulty since the early 1940s.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[290]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:ManoirdeBan.jpg" title="File:ManoirdeBan.jpg">File:ManoirdeBan.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Manoir_de_Ban&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Manoir de Ban (page does not exist)">Manoir de Ban</a>, Chaplin's home in <a href="/wiki/Corsier-sur-Vevey" title="Corsier-sur-Vevey">Corsier-sur-Vevey</a>, Switzerland</div></div></div>
<p>Chaplin remained a controversial figure throughout the 1950s, especially after he was awarded the <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Peace_Council_prizes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Peace Council prizes (page does not exist)">International Peace Prize</a> by the communist-led <a href="/wiki/World_Peace_Council" title="World Peace Council">World Peace Council</a>, and after his meetings with <a href="/wiki/Zhou_Enlai" title="Zhou Enlai">Zhou Enlai</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev" title="Nikita Khrushchev">Nikita Khrushchev</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[291]</a></sup> He began developing his first European film, <i><a href="/wiki/A_King_in_New_York" title="A King in New York">A King in New York</a></i>, in 1954.<sup id="cite_ref-Rob585_315-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rob585-315">[292]</a></sup> Casting himself as an exiled king who seeks asylum in the United States, Chaplin included several of his recent experiences in the screenplay. His son, Michael, was cast as a boy whose parents are targeted by the FBI, while Chaplin's character faces accusations of communism.<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">[293]</a></sup> The political satire parodied HUAC and attacked elements of 1950s culture – including consumerism, plastic surgery, and wide-screen cinema.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">[294]</a></sup> In a review, the playwright <a href="/wiki/John_Osborne" title="John Osborne">John Osborne</a> called it Chaplin's "most bitter" and "most openly personal" film.<sup id="cite_ref-RobRoi_318-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RobRoi-318">[295]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chaplin founded a new production company, Attica, and used <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shepperton_Studios&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shepperton Studios (page does not exist)">Shepperton Studios</a> for the shooting.<sup id="cite_ref-Rob585_315-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rob585-315">[292]</a></sup> Filming in England proved a difficult experience, as he was used to his own Hollywood studio and familiar crew, and no longer had limitless production time. According to Robinson, this had an effect on the quality of the film.<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[296]</a></sup> <i>A King in New York</i> was released in September 1957, and received mixed reviews.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[297]</a></sup> Chaplin banned American journalists from its Paris premiere, and decided not to release the film in the United States. This severely limited its revenue, although it achieved moderate commercial success in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[298]</a></sup> <i>A King in New York</i> was not shown in America until 1973.<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">[299]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Final_works_and_renewed_appreciation">Final works and renewed appreciation</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chaplin_family_1961.jpg" title="File:Chaplin family 1961.jpg">File:Chaplin family 1961.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Chaplin with his wife Oona and six of their children in 1961</div></div></div>
<p>In the last two decades of his career, Chaplin concentrated on re-editing and scoring his old films for re-release, along with securing their ownership and distribution rights.<sup id="cite_ref-Maland326_323-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Maland326-323">[300]</a></sup> In an interview he granted in 1959, the year of his 70th birthday, Chaplin stated that there was still "room for the Little Man in the atomic age".<sup id="cite_ref-Rob5945_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rob5945-324">[301]</a></sup> The first of these re-releases was <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Chaplin_Revue&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Chaplin Revue (page does not exist)">The Chaplin Revue</a></i> (1959), which included new versions of <i>A Dog's Life</i>, <i>Shoulder Arms</i>, and <i>The Pilgrim</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Rob5945_324-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rob5945-324">[301]</a></sup>
</p><p>In America, the political atmosphere began to change and attention was once again directed to Chaplin's films instead of his views.<sup id="cite_ref-Maland326_323-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Maland326-323">[300]</a></sup> In July 1962, <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i> published an editorial stating that "we do not believe the Republic would be in danger if yesterday's unforgotten little tramp were allowed to amble down the gangplank of a steamer or plane in an American port".<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">[302]</a></sup> The same month, Chaplin was invested with the <a href="/wiki/Honorary_degree" title="Honorary degree">honorary degree</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_of_Letters&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor of Letters (page does not exist)">Doctor of Letters</a> by the universities of <a href="/wiki/University_of_Oxford" title="University of Oxford">Oxford</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_Durham&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of Durham (page does not exist)">Durham</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Robinson.2C_pp._598.E2.80.93599_326-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Robinson.2C_pp._598.E2.80.93599-326">[303]</a></sup> In November 1963, the Plaza Theater in New York started a year-long series of Chaplin's films, including <i>Monsieur Verdoux</i> and <i>Limelight</i>, which gained excellent reviews from American critics.<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">[304]</a></sup> September 1964 saw the release of Chaplin's memoirs, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=My_Autobiography_(Chaplin)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="My Autobiography (Chaplin) (page does not exist)">My Autobiography</a></i>, which he had been working on since 1957.<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">[305]</a></sup> The 500-page book, which focused on his early years and personal life, became a worldwide best-seller, despite criticism over the lack of information on his film career.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">[306]</a></sup>
</p><p>Shortly after the publication of his memoirs, Chaplin began work on <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=A_Countess_from_Hong_Kong&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A Countess from Hong Kong (page does not exist)">A Countess from Hong Kong</a></i> (1967), a romantic comedy based on a script he had written for Paulette Goddard in the 1930s.<sup id="cite_ref-Robinson608_330-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Robinson608-330">[307]</a></sup> Set on an ocean liner, it starred <a href="/wiki/Marlon_Brando" title="Marlon Brando">Marlon Brando</a> as an American ambassador and <a href="/wiki/Sophia_Loren" title="Sophia Loren">Sophia Loren</a> as a stowaway found in his cabin.<sup id="cite_ref-Robinson608_330-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Robinson608-330">[307]</a></sup> The film differed from Chaplin's earlier productions in several aspects. It was his first to use <a href="/w/index.php?title=Technicolor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Technicolor (page does not exist)">Technicolor</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Widescreen" title="Widescreen">widescreen</a> format, while he concentrated on directing and appeared on-screen only in a cameo role as a seasick steward.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">[308]</a></sup> He also signed a deal with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Universal_Pictures&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Universal Pictures (page does not exist)">Universal Pictures</a> and appointed his assistant, Jerome Epstein, as the producer.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[309]</a></sup> <i>A Countess from Hong Kong</i> premiered in January 1967, to unfavourable reviews, and was a box-office failure.<sup id="cite_ref-Epsteinreviews_333-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Epsteinreviews-333">[310]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[311]</a></sup> Chaplin was deeply hurt by the negative reaction to the film, which turned out to be his last.<sup id="cite_ref-Epsteinreviews_333-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Epsteinreviews-333">[310]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chaplin_oscar.JPG" title="File:Chaplin oscar.JPG">File:Chaplin oscar.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Chaplin (right) receiving his <a href="/wiki/Honorary_Academy_Award" title="Honorary Academy Award" class="mw-redirect">Honorary Academy Award</a> from <a href="/wiki/Jack_Lemmon" title="Jack Lemmon">Jack Lemmon</a> in 1972. It was the first time he had returned to the United States in 20 years.</div></div></div>
<p>Chaplin suffered a series of minor strokes in the late 1960s, which marked the beginning of a slow decline in his health.<sup id="cite_ref-rob619_335-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rob619-335">[312]</a></sup> Despite the setbacks, he was soon writing a new film script, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Freak&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Freak (page does not exist)">The Freak</a></i>, a story of a winged girl found in South America, which he intended as a starring vehicle for his daughter, Victoria Chaplin.<sup id="cite_ref-rob619_335-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rob619-335">[312]</a></sup> His fragile health prevented the project from being realised.<sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">[313]</a></sup> In the early 1970s, Chaplin  concentrated on re-releasing his old films, including <i>The Kid</i> and <i>The Circus</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[314]</a></sup> In 1971, he was made a <a href="/wiki/Legion_of_Honour" title="Legion of Honour">Commander of the National Order of the Legion of Honour</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Cannes_Film_Festival" title="Cannes Film Festival">Cannes Film Festival</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-rob621_338-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rob621-338">[315]</a></sup> The following year, he was honoured with a special award by the <a href="/wiki/Venice_Film_Festival" title="Venice Film Festival">Venice Film Festival</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[316]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1972, the <a href="/wiki/Academy_of_Motion_Picture_Arts_and_Sciences" title="Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences">Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences</a> offered Chaplin an Honorary Award, which Robinson sees as a sign that America "wanted to make amends". Chaplin was initially hesitant about accepting, but decided to return to the US for the first time in 20 years.<sup id="cite_ref-rob621_338-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rob621-338">[315]</a></sup> The visit attracted a large amount of press coverage, and at the Academy Awards gala he was given a twelve-minute standing ovation, the longest in the Academy's history.<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[317]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[318]</a></sup> Visibly emotional, Chaplin accepted his award for "the incalculable effect he has had in making motion pictures the art form of this century".<sup id="cite_ref-oscar_342-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oscar-342">[319]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although Chaplin still had plans for future film projects, by the mid-1970s he was very frail.<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[320]</a></sup> He experienced several further strokes, which made it difficult for him to communicate, and he had to use a wheelchair.<sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">[321]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-EugeneChaplin_345-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EugeneChaplin-345">[322]</a></sup> His final projects were compiling a pictorial autobiography, <i>My Life in Pictures</i> (1974) and scoring <i>A Woman of Paris</i> for re-release in 1976.<sup id="cite_ref-Robilastyears_346-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Robilastyears-346">[323]</a></sup> He also appeared in a documentary about his life, <i>The Gentleman Tramp</i> (1975), directed by Richard Patterson.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[324]</a></sup> In 1975, Chaplin was awarded a knighthood by Queen <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elizabeth_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elizabeth II (page does not exist)">Elizabeth II</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Robilastyears_346-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Robilastyears-346">[323]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[note 24]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Charles_Chaplin_Grave_in_Corsier-sur-Vevey.jpg" title="File:Charles Chaplin Grave in Corsier-sur-Vevey.jpg">File:Charles Chaplin Grave in Corsier-sur-Vevey.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Chaplin's grave in Corsier-sur-Vevey, Switzerland</div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Death">Death</span></h4>
<p>By October 1977, Chaplin's health had declined to the point that he needed constant care.<sup id="cite_ref-rob629_350-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rob629-350">[326]</a></sup> In the early morning of 25 December 1977, he died at home after suffering a stroke in his sleep.<sup id="cite_ref-EugeneChaplin_345-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EugeneChaplin-345">[322]</a></sup> He was 88 years old. The funeral, on 27 December, was a small and private <a href="/wiki/Anglican" title="Anglican" class="mw-redirect">Anglican</a> ceremony, according to his wishes.<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">[note 25]</a></sup> Chaplin was interred in the Corsier-sur-Vevey cemetery.<sup id="cite_ref-rob629_350-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rob629-350">[326]</a></sup> Among the  film industry's tributes,  director <a href="/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Clair" title="René Clair">René Clair</a> wrote, "He was a monument of the cinema, of all countries and all times&#160;... the most beautiful gift the cinema made to us."<sup id="cite_ref-rob631_353-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rob631-353">[328]</a></sup> Actor <a href="/wiki/Bob_Hope" title="Bob Hope">Bob Hope</a> declared, "We were lucky to have lived in his time."<sup id="cite_ref-rob632_354-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rob632-354">[329]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 1 March 1978, Chaplin's coffin was dug up and stolen from its grave by two unemployed immigrants, Roman Wardas, from Poland, and Gantcho Ganev, from Bulgaria. The body was held for <a href="/wiki/Ransom" title="Ransom">ransom</a> in an attempt to extort money from Oona Chaplin. The pair were caught in a large police operation in May, and Chaplin's coffin was found buried in a field in the nearby village of <a href="/wiki/Noville,_Switzerland" title="Noville, Switzerland">Noville</a>. It was re-interred in the Corsier cemetery surrounded by reinforced concrete.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[330]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">[331]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Filmmaking">Filmmaking</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Influences">Influences</span></h3>
<p>Chaplin believed his first influence to be his mother, who would entertain him as a child by sitting at the window and mimicking passers-by: "it was through watching her that I learned not only how to express emotions with my hands and face, but also how to observe and study people."<sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">[332]</a></sup> Chaplin's early years in music hall allowed him to see stage comedians at work; he also attended the Christmas pantomimes at <a href="/wiki/Theatre_Royal,_Drury_Lane" title="Theatre Royal, Drury Lane">Drury Lane</a>, where he studied the art of clowning through performers like <a href="/wiki/Dan_Leno" title="Dan Leno">Dan Leno</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">[333]</a></sup> Chaplin's years with the Fred Karno company had a formative effect on him as an actor and filmmaker. Simon Louvish writes that the company was his "training ground",<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">[334]</a></sup> and it was here that Chaplin learnt to vary the pace of his comedy.<sup id="cite_ref-rob86_360-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rob86-360">[335]</a></sup> The concept of mixing pathos with slapstick was learnt from Karno,<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">[note 26]</a></sup> who also used elements of absurdity that became familiar in Chaplin's gags.<sup id="cite_ref-rob86_360-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rob86-360">[335]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">[336]</a></sup> From the film industry, Chaplin drew upon the work of the French comedian <a href="/wiki/Max_Linder" title="Max Linder">Max Linder</a>, whose films he greatly admired.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">[337]</a></sup> In developing the Tramp costume and persona, he was likely inspired by the American vaudeville scene, where tramp characters were common.<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">[338]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Method">Method</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chaplin_Studios_postcard.jpg" title="File:Chaplin Studios postcard.jpg">File:Chaplin Studios postcard.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A 1922 image of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charlie_Chaplin_Studios&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charlie Chaplin Studios (page does not exist)">Charlie Chaplin Studios</a>, where all of Chaplin's films between 1918 and 1952 were produced</div></div></div>
<p>Chaplin never spoke more than cursorily about his filmmaking methods, claiming such a thing would be tantamount to a magician spoiling his own illusion.<sup id="cite_ref-Rob606_365-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rob606-365">[339]</a></sup> Little was known about his working process throughout his lifetime,<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">[340]</a></sup> but research from film historians – particularly the findings of <a href="/wiki/Kevin_Brownlow" title="Kevin Brownlow">Kevin Brownlow</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=David_Gill_(film_historian)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="David Gill (film historian) (page does not exist)">David Gill</a> that were presented in the three-part documentary <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Unknown_Chaplin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Unknown Chaplin (page does not exist)">Unknown Chaplin</a></i> (1983) – has since revealed his unique working method.<sup id="cite_ref-LouRob_367-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LouRob-367">[341]</a></sup>
</p><p>Until he began making spoken dialogue films with <i>The Great Dictator</i>, Chaplin never shot from a completed script.<sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368">[342]</a></sup> Many of his early films began with only a vague premise – for example "Charlie enters a health spa" or "Charlie works in a pawn shop."<sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">[343]</a></sup> He then had sets constructed and worked with his stock company to improvise gags and "business" around them, almost always working the ideas out on film.<sup id="cite_ref-LouRob_367-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LouRob-367">[341]</a></sup> As ideas were accepted and discarded, a narrative structure would emerge, frequently requiring Chaplin to reshoot an already-completed scene that might have otherwise contradicted the story.<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">[344]</a></sup> From <i>A Woman of Paris</i> onward Chaplin began the filming process with a prepared plot,<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">[345]</a></sup> but Robinson writes that every film up to <i>Modern Times</i> "went through many metamorphoses and permutations before the story took its final form."<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">[346]</a></sup>
</p><p>Producing films in this manner meant Chaplin took longer to complete his pictures than almost any other filmmaker at the time.<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">[347]</a></sup> If he was out of ideas he often took a break from the shoot, which could last for days, while keeping the studio ready for when inspiration returned.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[348]</a></sup> Delaying the process further was Chaplin's rigorous perfectionism.<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[349]</a></sup> According to his friend <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ivor_Montagu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ivor Montagu (page does not exist)">Ivor Montagu</a>, "nothing but perfection would be right" for the filmmaker.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[350]</a></sup> Because he personally funded his films, Chaplin was at liberty to strive for this goal and shoot as many takes as he wished.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[351]</a></sup> The number was often excessive, for instance 53 takes for every finished take in <i>The Kid</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">[352]</a></sup> For <i>The Immigrant</i>, a 20 minute-short, Chaplin shot 40,000 feet of film – enough for a feature-length.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[353]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="quotebox" style="float: left; clear: left; margin: 0.5em 1.4em 0.8em 0; width: 20%; padding: 6px; border: 1px solid #aaa; font-size: 88%; background-color: #E0E6F8;">
<div style="position: relative; text-align: left;">
<div>
<p>"No other filmmaker ever so completely dominated every aspect of the work, did every job. If he could have done so, Chaplin would have played every role and (as his son Sydney humorously but perceptively observed) sewn every costume."<sup id="cite_ref-Rob606_365-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rob606-365">[339]</a></sup>
</p>
</div>
</div>
<div style="text-align: left;">—Chaplin biographer <a href="/wiki/David_Robinson_(film_critic)" title="David Robinson (film critic)">David Robinson</a></div>
</div>
<p>Describing his working method as "sheer perseverance to the point of madness",<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">[354]</a></sup> Chaplin would be completely consumed by the production of a picture.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[355]</a></sup> Robinson writes that even in Chaplin's later years, his work continued "to take precedence over everything and everyone else."<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">[356]</a></sup> The combination of story improvisation and relentless perfectionism – which resulted in days of effort and thousands of feet of film being wasted, all at enormous expense – often proved taxing for Chaplin who, in frustration, would lash out at his actors and crew.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">[357]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chaplin exercised complete control over his pictures,<sup id="cite_ref-Rob606_365-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rob606-365">[339]</a></sup> to the extent that he would act out the other roles for his cast, expecting them to imitate him exactly.<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">[358]</a></sup> He personally edited all of his films, trawling through the large amounts of footage to create the exact picture he wanted.<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">[359]</a></sup> As a result of his complete independence, he was identified by the film historian <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Sarris" title="Andrew Sarris">Andrew Sarris</a> as one of the first <a href="/w/index.php?title=Auteur&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Auteur (page does not exist)">auteur</a> filmmakers.<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">[360]</a></sup> Chaplin did receive help, notably from his long-time cinematographer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roland_Totheroh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roland Totheroh (page does not exist)">Roland Totheroh</a>, brother Sydney Chaplin, and various <a href="/w/index.php?title=Assistant_directors&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Assistant directors (page does not exist)">assistant directors</a> such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Harry_Crocker&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Harry Crocker (page does not exist)">Harry Crocker</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charles_Reisner&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charles Reisner (page does not exist)">Charles Reisner</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">[361]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Style_and_themes">Style and themes</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Kid_scenes.ogv" title="File:The Kid scenes.ogv">File:The Kid scenes.ogv</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A collection of scenes from <i><a href="/wiki/The_Kid_(1921_film)" title="The Kid (1921 film)">The Kid</a></i> (1921), demonstrating Chaplin's mixture of slapstick, pathos, and social commentary</div></div></div>
<p>While Chaplin's comedic style is broadly defined as <a href="/wiki/Slapstick" title="Slapstick">slapstick</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[362]</a></sup> it is considered restrained and intelligent,<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[363]</a></sup> with the film historian Philip Kemp describing his work as a mix of "deft, balletic physical comedy and thoughtful, situation-based gags".<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[364]</a></sup> Chaplin diverged from conventional slapstick by slowing the pace and exhausting each scene of its comic potential, with more focus on developing the viewer's relationship to the characters.<sup id="cite_ref-robi2_73-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-robi2-73">[65]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Mast1_391-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mast1-391">[365]</a></sup> Unlike conventional slapstick comedies, Robinson states that the comic moments in Chaplin's films centre on the Tramp's attitude to the things happening to him: the humour does not come from the Tramp bumping into a tree, but from his lifting his hat to the tree in apology.<sup id="cite_ref-robi2_73-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-robi2-73">[65]</a></sup> Dan Kamin writes that Chaplin's "quirky mannerisms" and "serious demeanour in the midst of slapstick action" are other key aspects of his comedy,<sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">[366]</a></sup> while the surreal transformation of objects and the employment of <a href="/wiki/In-camera_effect" title="In-camera effect">in-camera</a> trickery are also common features.<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">[367]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chaplin's silent films typically follow the Tramp's efforts to survive in a hostile world.<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">[368]</a></sup> The character lives in poverty and is frequently treated badly, but remains kind and upbeat;<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">[369]</a></sup> defying his social position, he strives to be seen as a gentleman.<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">[370]</a></sup> As Chaplin said in 1925, "The whole point of the Little Fellow is that no matter how down on his ass he is, no matter how well the jackals succeed in tearing him apart, he's still a man of dignity."<sup id="cite_ref-weiss_47_397-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-weiss_47-397">[371]</a></sup> The Tramp defies authority figures<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">[372]</a></sup> and "gives as good as he gets",<sup id="cite_ref-weiss_47_397-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-weiss_47-397">[371]</a></sup> leading Robinson and Louvish to see him as a representative for the underprivileged – an "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Everyman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Everyman (page does not exist)">everyman</a> turned heroic saviour".<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">[373]</a></sup> Hansmeyer notes that several of Chaplin's films end with "the homeless and lonely Tramp [walking] optimistically&#160;... into the sunset&#160;... to continue his journey".<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">[374]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="quotebox" style="float: left; clear: left; margin: 0.5em 1.4em 0.8em 0; width: 20%; padding: 6px; border: 1px solid #aaa; font-size: 88%; background-color: #E0E6F8;">
<div style="position: relative; text-align: left;">
<div>
<p>"It is paradoxical that tragedy stimulates the spirit of ridicule&#160;... ridicule, I suppose, is an attitude of defiance; we must laugh in the face of our helplessness against the forces of nature – or go insane."<sup id="cite_ref-Robi5_401-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Robi5-401">[375]</a></sup>
</p>
</div>
</div>
<div style="text-align: left;">—Chaplin explaining why his comedies often make fun of tragic circumstances</div>
</div>
<p>The infusion of <a href="/wiki/Pathos" title="Pathos">pathos</a> is a well-known aspect of Chaplin's work,<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">[376]</a></sup> and Larcher notes his reputation for "[inducing] laughter and tears".<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">[377]</a></sup> Sentimentality in his films come from a variety of sources, with Louvish pinpointing "personal failure, society's strictures, economic disaster, and the elements."<sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">[378]</a></sup> Chaplin sometimes drew on tragic events when creating his films, as in the case of <i>The Gold Rush</i> (1925), which was inspired by the fate of the Donner Party.<sup id="cite_ref-Robi5_401-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Robi5-401">[375]</a></sup> Constance B. Kuriyama has identified serious underlying themes in the early comedies, such as greed (<i>The Gold Rush</i>) and loss (<i>The Kid</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">[379]</a></sup> Chaplin also touched on controversial issues: immigration (<i>The Immigrant</i>, 1917); illegitimacy (<i>The Kid</i>, 1921); and drug use (<i>Easy Street</i>, 1917).<sup id="cite_ref-Mast1_391-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mast1-391">[365]</a></sup> He often explored these topics ironically, making comedy out of suffering.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">[380]</a></sup>
</p><p>Social commentary was a feature of Chaplin's films from early in his career, as he portrayed the underdog in a sympathetic light and highlighted the difficulties of the poor.<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">[381]</a></sup> Later, as he developed a keen interest in economics and felt obliged to publicise his views,<sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">[382]</a></sup> Chaplin began incorporating overtly political messages into his films.<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">[383]</a></sup> <i>Modern Times</i> (1936) depicted factory workers in dismal conditions, <i>The Great Dictator</i> (1940) parodied <a href="/w/index.php?title=Adolf_Hitler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adolf Hitler (page does not exist)">Adolf Hitler</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Benito_Mussolini&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Benito Mussolini (page does not exist)">Benito Mussolini</a> and ended in a speech against nationalism, <i>Monsieur Verdoux</i> (1947) criticised war and capitalism, and <i>A King in New York</i> (1957) attacked <a href="/wiki/McCarthyism" title="McCarthyism">McCarthyism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">[384]</a></sup>
</p><p>Several of Chaplin's films incorporate autobiographical elements, and the psychologist <a href="/wiki/Sigmund_Freud" title="Sigmund Freud">Sigmund Freud</a> believed that Chaplin "always plays only himself as he was in his dismal youth".<sup id="cite_ref-Weissmann2_411-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Weissmann2-411">[385]</a></sup> <i>The Kid</i> is thought to reflect Chaplin's childhood trauma of being sent into an orphanage,<sup id="cite_ref-Weissmann2_411-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Weissmann2-411">[385]</a></sup> the main characters in <i>Limelight</i> (1952) contain elements from the lives of his parents,<sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">[386]</a></sup> and <i>A King in New York</i> references Chaplin's experiences of being shunned by the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">[387]</a></sup> Many of his sets, especially in street scenes, bear a strong similarity to Kennington, where he grew up. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stephen_M._Weissman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stephen M. Weissman (page does not exist)">Stephen M. Weissman</a> has argued that Chaplin's problematic relationship with his mentally ill mother was often reflected in his female characters and the Tramp's desire to save them.<sup id="cite_ref-Weissmann2_411-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Weissmann2-411">[385]</a></sup>
</p><p>Regarding the structure of Chaplin's films, the scholar <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gerald_Mast&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gerald Mast (page does not exist)">Gerald Mast</a> sees them as consisting of sketches tied together by the same theme and setting, rather than having a tightly unified storyline.<sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">[388]</a></sup> Visually, his films are simple and economic,<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">[389]</a></sup> with scenes portrayed as if set on a stage.<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">[390]</a></sup> His approach to filming was described by the art director <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eug%C3%A8ne_Louri%C3%A9&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eugène Lourié (page does not exist)">Eugène Lourié</a>: "Chaplin did not think in 'artistic' images when he was shooting. He believed that action is the main thing. The camera is there to photograph the actors".<sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">[391]</a></sup> In his autobiography, Chaplin wrote, "Simplicity is best&#160;... pompous effects slow up action, are boring and unpleasant&#160;... The camera should not intrude."<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">[392]</a></sup> This approach has prompted criticism, since the 1940s, for being "old fashioned",<sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419">[393]</a></sup> while the film scholar Donald McCaffrey sees it as an indication that Chaplin never completely understood film as a medium.<sup id="cite_ref-McCaffrey1_420-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McCaffrey1-420">[394]</a></sup> Kamin, however, comments that Chaplin's comedic talent would not be enough to remain funny on screen if he did not have an "ability to conceive and direct scenes specifically for the film medium".<sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">[395]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Composing">Composing</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Charlie_Chaplin_playing_the_cello_1915.jpg" title="File:Charlie Chaplin playing the cello 1915.jpg">File:Charlie Chaplin playing the cello 1915.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Chaplin playing the cello in 1915</div></div></div>
<p>Chaplin developed a passion for music as a child, and taught himself to play the piano, violin, and cello.<sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">[396]</a></sup> He considered the musical accompaniment of a film to be important,<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_181-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-181">[170]</a></sup> and from <i>A Woman of Paris</i> onwards he took an increasing interest in this area.<sup id="cite_ref-Rob_411_423-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rob_411-423">[397]</a></sup> With the advent of sound technology, Chaplin began using a synchronised orchestral soundtrack – composed by himself – for <i>City Lights</i> (1931). He thereafter composed the scores for all of his films, and from the late 1950s to his death, he scored all of his silent features and some of his short films.<sup id="cite_ref-VarietyVance_424-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VarietyVance-424">[398]</a></sup>
</p><p>As Chaplin was not a trained musician, he could not read sheet music and needed the help of professional composers, such as <a href="/wiki/David_Raksin" title="David Raksin">David Raksin</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Raymond_Rasch&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Raymond Rasch (page does not exist)">Raymond Rasch</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eric_James&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eric James (page does not exist)">Eric James</a>, when creating his scores. Although some critics have claimed that credit for his film music should be given to the composers who worked with him, Raksin – who worked with Chaplin on <i>Modern Times</i> – has stressed Chaplin's creative position and active participation in the composing process.<sup id="cite_ref-Raksin1_425-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Raksin1-425">[399]</a></sup> This process, which could take months, would start with Chaplin describing to the composer(s) exactly what he wanted and singing or playing tunes he had improvised on the piano.<sup id="cite_ref-Raksin1_425-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Raksin1-425">[399]</a></sup> These tunes were then developed further in a close collaboration among the composer(s) and Chaplin.<sup id="cite_ref-Raksin1_425-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Raksin1-425">[399]</a></sup> According to film historian Jeffrey Vance, "although he relied upon associates to arrange varied and complex instrumentation, the musical imperative is his, and not a note in a Chaplin musical score was placed there without his assent."<sup id="cite_ref-VarietyVance_424-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VarietyVance-424">[398]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chaplin's compositions produced three popular songs. "<a href="/wiki/Smile_(Charlie_Chaplin_song)" title="Smile (Charlie Chaplin song)">Smile</a>", composed originally for <i>Modern Times</i> (1936) and later set to lyrics by <a href="/wiki/John_Turner_(lyricist)" title="John Turner (lyricist)">John Turner</a> and <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_Parsons_(lyricist)" title="Geoffrey Parsons (lyricist)">Geoffrey Parsons</a>, was a hit for <a href="/wiki/Nat_King_Cole" title="Nat King Cole">Nat King Cole</a> in 1954.<sup id="cite_ref-VarietyVance_424-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VarietyVance-424">[398]</a></sup> For <i>Limelight</i>, Chaplin composed "Terry's Theme", which was popularised by <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Young_(disc_jockey)" title="Jimmy Young (disc jockey)">Jimmy Young</a> as "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Eternally_(1952_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eternally (1952 song) (page does not exist)">Eternally</a>" (1952).<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">[400]</a></sup> Finally, "<a href="/wiki/This_Is_My_Song_(1967_song)" title="This Is My Song (1967 song)">This Is My Song</a>", performed by <a href="/wiki/Petula_Clark" title="Petula Clark">Petula Clark</a> for <i>A Countess from Hong Kong</i> (1967), reached number one on the UK and other European charts.<sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427">[401]</a></sup> Chaplin also received his only competitive Oscar for his composition work, as the <i>Limelight</i> theme won an <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Score" title="Academy Award for Best Original Score">Academy Award for Best Original Score</a> in 1973 following the film's re-release.<sup id="cite_ref-VarietyVance_424-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VarietyVance-424">[398]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">[note 27]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy">Legacy</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Tramp_Essanay.jpg" title="File:The Tramp Essanay.jpg">File:The Tramp Essanay.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Chaplin as <a href="/wiki/The_Tramp" title="The Tramp">the Tramp</a> in 1915, cinema's "most universal icon"<sup id="cite_ref-sarris139_430-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sarris139-430">[403]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In 1998, the film critic Andrew Sarris called Chaplin "arguably the single most important artist produced by the cinema, certainly its most extraordinary performer and probably still its most universal icon".<sup id="cite_ref-sarris139_430-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sarris139-430">[403]</a></sup> He is described by the British Film Institute as "a towering figure in world culture",<sup id="cite_ref-BFIChaplinproject_431-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BFIChaplinproject-431">[404]</a></sup> and was included in <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">TIME</a></i> magazine's list of the "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Time_100:_The_Most_Important_People_of_the_Century&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Time 100: The Most Important People of the Century (page does not exist)">100 Most Important People of the 20th Century</a>" for the "laughter [he brought] to millions" and because he "more or less invented global recognizability and helped turn an industry into an art".<sup id="cite_ref-time_100_432-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-time_100-432">[405]</a></sup>
</p><p>The image of the Tramp has become a part of cultural history;<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">[406]</a></sup> according to Simon Louvish, the character is recognisable to people who have never seen a Chaplin film, and in places where his films are never shown.<sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">[407]</a></sup> The critic <a href="/wiki/Leonard_Maltin" title="Leonard Maltin">Leonard Maltin</a> has written of the "unique" and "indelible" nature of the Tramp, and argued that no other comedian matched his "worldwide impact".<sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435">[408]</a></sup> Praising the character, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Richard_Schickel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Richard Schickel (page does not exist)">Richard Schickel</a> suggests that Chaplin's films with the Tramp contain the most "eloquent, richly comedic expressions of the human spirit" in movie history.<sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436">[409]</a></sup> Memorabilia connected to the character still fetches large sums in auctions: in 2006 a bowler hat and a bamboo cane that were part of the Tramp's costume were bought for $140,000 in a Los Angeles auction.<sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437">[410]</a></sup>
</p><p>As a filmmaker, Chaplin is considered a pioneer and one of the most influential figures of the early twentieth century.<sup id="cite_ref-acclaim_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-acclaim-1">[1]</a></sup> He is often credited as one of the medium's first artists.<sup id="cite_ref-438" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-438">[411]</a></sup> Film historian <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mark_Cousins_(film_critic)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mark Cousins (film critic) (page does not exist)">Mark Cousins</a> has written that Chaplin "changed not only the imagery of cinema, but also its sociology and grammar" and claims that Chaplin was as important to the development of comedy as a genre as <a href="/wiki/D.W._Griffith" title="D.W. Griffith" class="mw-redirect">D.W. Griffith</a> was to drama.<sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439">[412]</a></sup> He was the first to popularise feature-length comedy and to slow down the pace of action, adding pathos and subtlety to it.<sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440">[413]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-silent_clowns_441-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-silent_clowns-441">[414]</a></sup> Although his work is mostly classified as slapstick, Chaplin's drama <i>A Woman of Paris</i> (1923) was a major influence on <a href="/wiki/Ernst_Lubitsch" title="Ernst Lubitsch">Ernst Lubitsch</a>'s film <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Marriage_Circle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Marriage Circle (page does not exist)">The Marriage Circle</a></i> (1924) and thus played a part in the development of   "sophisticated comedy".<sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442">[415]</a></sup> According to David Robinson, Chaplin's innovations were "rapidly assimilated to become part of the common practice of film craft."<sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443">[416]</a></sup> Filmmakers who cited Chaplin as an influence include <a href="/wiki/Federico_Fellini" title="Federico Fellini">Federico Fellini</a> (who called Chaplin "a sort of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Adam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adam (page does not exist)">Adam</a>, from whom we are all descended"),<sup id="cite_ref-rob632_354-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rob632-354">[329]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Tati" title="Jacques Tati">Jacques Tati</a> ("Without him I would never have made a film"),<sup id="cite_ref-rob632_354-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rob632-354">[329]</a></sup> René Clair ("He inspired practically every filmmaker"),<sup id="cite_ref-rob631_353-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rob631-353">[328]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Michael_Powell" title="Michael Powell">Michael Powell</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444">[417]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Billy_Wilder" title="Billy Wilder">Billy Wilder</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-story_of_film_445-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-story_of_film-445">[418]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Richard_Attenborough&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Richard Attenborough (page does not exist)">Richard Attenborough</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-446" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-446">[419]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Andrei_Tarkovsky" title="Andrei Tarkovsky">Andrei Tarkovsky</a> praised Chaplin as "the only person to have gone down into cinematic history without any shadow of a doubt. The films he left behind can never grow old."<sup id="cite_ref-tarovsky_447-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tarovsky-447">[420]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chaplin also strongly influenced the work of later comedians. <a href="/wiki/Marcel_Marceau" title="Marcel Marceau">Marcel Marceau</a> said he was inspired to become a mime artist after watching Chaplin,<sup id="cite_ref-silent_clowns_441-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-silent_clowns-441">[414]</a></sup> while the actor <a href="/wiki/Raj_Kapoor" title="Raj Kapoor">Raj Kapoor</a> based his screen persona on the Tramp.<sup id="cite_ref-story_of_film_445-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-story_of_film-445">[418]</a></sup> Mark Cousins has also detected Chaplin's comedic style in the French character <a href="/wiki/Monsieur_Hulot" title="Monsieur Hulot">Monsieur Hulot</a> and the Italian character <a href="/wiki/Tot%C3%B2" title="Totò">Totò</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-story_of_film_445-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-story_of_film-445">[418]</a></sup> In other fields, Chaplin helped inspire the cartoon characters <a href="/wiki/Felix_the_Cat" title="Felix the Cat">Felix the Cat</a><sup id="cite_ref-448" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-448">[421]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Mickey_Mouse" title="Mickey Mouse">Mickey Mouse</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-449" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-449">[422]</a></sup> and was an influence on the <a href="/wiki/Dada" title="Dada">Dada</a> art movement.<sup id="cite_ref-450" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450">[423]</a></sup> As one of the founding members of United Artists, Chaplin also had a role in the development of the film industry. Gerald Mast has written that although UA never became a major company like <a href="/w/index.php?title=MGM&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MGM (page does not exist)">MGM</a> or <a href="/wiki/Paramount_Pictures" title="Paramount Pictures">Paramount Pictures</a>, the idea that directors could produce their own films was "years ahead of its time".<sup id="cite_ref-451" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-451">[424]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 21st century, several of Chaplin's films are still regarded as classics and among the greatest ever made.  The 2012 <i><a href="/wiki/Sight_%26_Sound" title="Sight &amp; Sound">Sight &amp; Sound</a></i> poll, which compiles "top ten" ballots from film critics and directors to determine each group's most acclaimed films,
saw <i>City Lights</i> rank among the critics' top 50, <i>Modern Times</i> inside the top 100, and <i>The Great Dictator</i> and <i>The Gold Rush</i> placed in the top 250.<sup id="cite_ref-452" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-452">[425]</a></sup> The top 100 films as voted on by directors included <i>Modern Times</i> at number 22, <i>City Lights</i> at number 30, and <i>The Gold Rush</i> at number 91.<sup id="cite_ref-453" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-453">[426]</a></sup> Every one of Chaplin's features received a vote.<sup id="cite_ref-454" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-454">[427]</a></sup> In 2007, the <a href="/wiki/American_Film_Institute" title="American Film Institute">American Film Institute</a> named <i>City Lights</i> the 11th <a href="/w/index.php?title=AFI%27s_100_Years...100_Movies_(10th_Anniversary_Edition)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="AFI's 100 Years...100 Movies (10th Anniversary Edition) (page does not exist)">greatest American film of all time</a>, while <i>The Gold Rush</i> and <i>Modern Times</i> again ranked in the top 100.<sup id="cite_ref-455" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-455">[428]</a></sup> Books about Chaplin continue to be published regularly, and he is a popular subject for media scholars and film archivists.<sup id="cite_ref-456" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-456">[429]</a></sup> Many of Chaplin's film have had a <a href="/w/index.php?title=DVD&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="DVD (page does not exist)">DVD</a> and <a href="/wiki/Blu-Ray" title="Blu-Ray" class="mw-redirect">Blu-Ray</a> release.<sup id="cite_ref-457" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-457">[430]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Commemoration_and_tributes">Commemoration and tributes</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Charlie_Chaplin-Leicester_Square-London.jpg" title="File:Charlie Chaplin-Leicester Square-London.jpg">File:Charlie Chaplin-Leicester Square-London.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Statue of Chaplin in London's <a href="/wiki/Leicester_Square" title="Leicester Square">Leicester Square</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Doubleday&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Doubleday (page does not exist)">John Doubleday</a>, 1981)</div></div></div>
<p>Several memorials have been dedicated to Chaplin. In his home city, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=London_Film_Museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="London Film Museum (page does not exist)">London Film Museum</a> hosts a permanent exhibition on his life and career called <i>Charlie Chaplin – The Great Londoner</i>, which opened in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-458" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-458">[431]</a></sup> A statue of Chaplin as the Tramp is located in <a href="/wiki/Leicester_Square" title="Leicester Square">Leicester Square</a>, sculpted by <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Doubleday&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Doubleday (page does not exist)">John Doubleday</a> and unveiled in 1981.<sup id="cite_ref-rob677_459-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rob677-459">[432]</a></sup> The city also includes a road named after him, "Charlie Chaplin Walk" in central London, which is the location of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=BFI_IMAX&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BFI IMAX (page does not exist)">BFI IMAX</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-460" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-460">[433]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chaplin's final home, Manoir de Ban in Corsier-sur-Vevey, Switzerland, is in the process of being converted into a museum, to be opened in 2015, exploring his life and career.<sup id="cite_ref-461" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-461">[434]</a></sup> The nearby town of <a href="/wiki/Vevey" title="Vevey">Vevey</a> named a park in his honour in 1980 and erected a statue there in 1982.<sup id="cite_ref-rob677_459-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rob677-459">[432]</a></sup> In 2011, two large murals depicting Chaplin on two 14-storey buildings were also unveiled in Vevey.<sup id="cite_ref-462" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-462">[435]</a></sup> Chaplin has also been honoured by the Irish town of <a href="/wiki/Waterville,_County_Kerry" title="Waterville, County Kerry">Waterville</a>, where he spent several summers with his family in the 1960s. A statue was erected in 1998,<sup id="cite_ref-463" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-463">[436]</a></sup> and since 2011 the town has been host to the annual Charlie Chaplin Comedy Film Festival, which was founded to celebrate Chaplin's legacy and to showcase new comic talent.<sup id="cite_ref-464" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-464">[437]</a></sup>
