</p><p>In other tributes, a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Minor_planet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Minor planet (page does not exist)">minor planet</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=3623_Chaplin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="3623 Chaplin (page does not exist)">3623 Chaplin</a> – discovered by <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet</a> astronomer <a href="/wiki/Lyudmila_Karachkina" title="Lyudmila Karachkina">Lyudmila Karachkina</a> in 1981 – is named after Chaplin.<sup id="cite_ref-465" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-465">[438]</a></sup> Throughout the 1980s, the Tramp image was used by <a href="/w/index.php?title=IBM&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="IBM (page does not exist)">IBM</a> to advertise their personal computers.<sup id="cite_ref-466" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-466">[439]</a></sup> Chaplin's 100th birthday anniversary in 1989 was marked with several events around the world,<sup id="cite_ref-470" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-470">[note 28]</a></sup> and on 15 April 2011, a day before his 122nd birthday, <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">Google</a> celebrated him with a special <a href="/wiki/Google_Doodle" title="Google Doodle" class="mw-redirect">Google Doodle</a> video on its global and other country-wide homepages.<sup id="cite_ref-471" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-471">[443]</a></sup> Many countries, spanning six continents, have honoured Chaplin with a postal stamp.<sup id="cite_ref-472" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-472">[444]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chaplin's legacy is managed by Association Chaplin, a company founded by some of his children, which owns the copyrights to his image, name, and most of his films made after 1918.<sup id="cite_ref-473" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-473">[445]</a></sup> Their central archive is held at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cineteca_di_Bologna&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cineteca di Bologna (page does not exist)">Cineteca di Bologna</a> and includes 83,630 images, 118 scripts, 976 manuscripts, 7,756 letters, and thousands of documents.<sup id="cite_ref-474" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-474">[446]</a></sup> The photographic archive, which includes approximately 10,000 photographs from Chaplin's life and career, is kept at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mus%C3%A9e_de_l%27Elys%C3%A9e&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Musée de l'Elysée (page does not exist)">Musée de l'Elysée</a> in <a href="/wiki/Lausanne" title="Lausanne">Lausanne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-475" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-475">[447]</a></sup> The British Film Institute has also established the Charles Chaplin Research Foundation, and the first international Charles Chaplin Conference was held in London in July 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-476" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-476">[448]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Characterisations">Characterisations</span></h3>
<p>Chaplin is the subject of a <a href="/wiki/Biographical_film" title="Biographical film">biographical film</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Chaplin_(film)" title="Chaplin (film)">Chaplin</a></i> (1992, directed by Richard Attenborough). It stars <a href="/wiki/Robert_Downey,_Jr." title="Robert Downey, Jr.">Robert Downey, Jr.</a>, who was nominated for an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_Award_for_Best_Actor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy Award for Best Actor (page does not exist)">Academy Award for Best Actor</a> and won a <a href="/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Actor" title="BAFTA Award for Best Actor" class="mw-redirect">BAFTA Award for Best Actor</a> for his performance.<sup id="cite_ref-477" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-477">[449]</a></sup> Chaplin is also a character in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Cat%27s_Meow" title="The Cat's Meow">The Cat's Meow</a></i> (2001), played by <a href="/wiki/Eddie_Izzard" title="Eddie Izzard">Eddie Izzard</a>, and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Scarlett_O%27Hara_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Scarlett O'Hara War (page does not exist)">The Scarlett O'Hara War</a></i> (1980), played by <a href="/wiki/Clive_Revill" title="Clive Revill">Clive Revill</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-478" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-478">[450]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-479" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-479">[451]</a></sup> A television series about Chaplin's childhood, <i>Young Charlie Chaplin</i>, ran on <a href="/w/index.php?title=PBS&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="PBS (page does not exist)">PBS</a> in 1989 and was nominated for an <a href="/wiki/Emmy_Award" title="Emmy Award">Emmy Award</a> for Outstanding Children's Program.<sup id="cite_ref-480" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-480">[452]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chaplin's life has also been the subject of stage productions. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thomas_Meehan_(writer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thomas Meehan (writer) (page does not exist)">Thomas Meehan</a> and Christopher Curtis created a musical, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Limelight:_The_Story_of_Charlie_Chaplin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Limelight: The Story of Charlie Chaplin (page does not exist)">Limelight: The Story of Charlie Chaplin</a></i>, which was first performed at the <a href="/wiki/La_Jolla_Playhouse" title="La Jolla Playhouse">La Jolla Playhouse</a> in San Diego in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-481" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-481">[453]</a></sup> It was adapted for <a href="/wiki/Broadway_Theatre" title="Broadway Theatre" class="mw-redirect">Broadway</a> two years later, retitled <i>Chaplin – A Musical</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-482" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-482">[454]</a></sup> Chaplin was portrayed by Robert McClure in both productions. In 2013, two plays about Chaplin premiered in <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">Finland</a>: <i>Chaplin</i> at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Svenska_Teatern&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Svenska Teatern (page does not exist)">Svenska Teatern</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-ChaplinFinland_483-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ChaplinFinland-483">[455]</a></sup> and <i>Kulkuri</i> (<i>The Tramp</i>) at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tampere_Workers%27_Theatre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tampere Workers' Theatre (page does not exist)">Tampere Workers' Theatre</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-484" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-484">[456]</a></sup> Chaplin is also the central character in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Glen_David_Gold&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Glen David Gold (page does not exist)">Glen David Gold</a>'s novel <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sunnyside_(novel)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sunnyside (novel) (page does not exist)">Sunnyside</a></i> (2009), which is set in the First World War period.<sup id="cite_ref-485" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-485">[457]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards_and_recognition">Awards and recognition</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Charlie_Chaplin_walk_of_fame.jpg" title="File:Charlie Chaplin walk of fame.jpg">File:Charlie Chaplin walk of fame.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Chaplin's star on the <a href="/wiki/Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame" title="Hollywood Walk of Fame">Hollywood Walk of Fame</a>, located at 6755 Hollywood Boulevard. Although the project started in 1958, Chaplin only received his star in 1970 because of his political views.</div></div></div>
<p>Chaplin received many awards and honours, especially later in life. In the <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Year_Honours&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Year Honours (page does not exist)">New Year Honours</a> 1975, he was appointed a <a href="/wiki/Knight_Commander_of_the_Most_Excellent_Order_of_the_British_Empire" title="Knight Commander of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire" class="mw-redirect">Knight Commander of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-486" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-486">[458]</a></sup> He was also awarded honorary Doctor of Letters degrees by the University of Oxford and the University of Durham in 1962.<sup id="cite_ref-Robinson.2C_pp._598.E2.80.93599_326-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Robinson.2C_pp._598.E2.80.93599-326">[303]</a></sup> In 1965 he and <a href="/wiki/Ingmar_Bergman" title="Ingmar Bergman">Ingmar Bergman</a> were joint winners of the <a href="/wiki/Erasmus_Prize" title="Erasmus Prize">Erasmus Prize</a><sup id="cite_ref-487" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-487">[459]</a></sup> and in 1971 he was appointed a Commander of the National Order of the Legion of Honour by the French government.<sup id="cite_ref-488" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-488">[460]</a></sup>
</p><p>From the film industry, Chaplin received a special <a href="/w/index.php?title=Golden_Lion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Golden Lion (page does not exist)">Golden Lion</a> at the Venice Film Festival in 1972,<sup id="cite_ref-489" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-489">[461]</a></sup> and a Lifetime Achievement Award from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lincoln_Center_Film_Society&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lincoln Center Film Society (page does not exist)">Lincoln Center Film Society</a> the same year. The latter has since been presented annually to filmmakers as The Chaplin Award.<sup id="cite_ref-490" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-490">[462]</a></sup> Chaplin was given a star on the <a href="/wiki/Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame" title="Hollywood Walk of Fame">Hollywood Walk of Fame</a> in 1970, having been previously  excluded  because of his political beliefs.<sup id="cite_ref-491" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-491">[463]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chaplin received three <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy Award (page does not exist)">Academy Awards</a>: an <a href="/wiki/Academy_Honorary_Award" title="Academy Honorary Award">Honorary Award</a> for "versatility and genius in acting, writing, directing and producing <i>The Circus</i>" in 1929,<sup id="cite_ref-circus_182-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-circus-182">[171]</a></sup> a second Honorary Award for "the incalculable effect he has had in making motion pictures the art form of this century" in 1972,<sup id="cite_ref-oscar_342-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oscar-342">[319]</a></sup> and a <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Score" title="Academy Award for Best Original Score">Best Score</a> award in 1973 for <i>Limelight</i> (shared with Ray Rasch and Larry Russell).<sup id="cite_ref-VarietyVance_424-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VarietyVance-424">[398]</a></sup> He was further nominated in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_Award_for_Best_Actor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy Award for Best Actor (page does not exist)">Best Actor</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Screenplay&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay (page does not exist)">Best Original Screenplay</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Best Picture</a> (as producer) categories for <i>The Great Dictator</i>, and received another Best Original Screenplay nomination for <i>Monsieur Verdoux</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-492" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-492">[464]</a></sup>
</p><p>Six of Chaplin's films have been selected for preservation in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Film_Registry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Film Registry (page does not exist)">National Film Registry</a> by the United States <a href="/w/index.php?title=Library_of_Congress&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Library of Congress (page does not exist)">Library of Congress</a>: <i>The Immigrant</i> (1917), <i>The Kid</i> (1921), <i>The Gold Rush</i> (1925), <i>City Lights</i> (1931), <i>Modern Times</i> (1936), and <i>The Great Dictator</i> (1940).<sup id="cite_ref-493" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-493">[465]</a></sup>
</p>
